{"uri": "8234029401", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "19:06:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T19:06:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T19:04:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://techbullion.com/how-artificial-intelligence-is-revolutionizing-pcbs/", "title": "How Artificial Intelligence is Revolutionizing PCBs", "body": "The tiny circuits hidden inside your electronics, from smartphones to laptops, are the brains of the operation. These intricate networks, called printed circuit boards (PCBs), connect all the little components that make your devices work.\n\nDesigning these PCBs can be tricky, like a complex puzzle. Everything needs to fit just right, and electricity needs to flow smoothly. This can be slow and error-prone, but that's where Artificial Intelligence (AI) comes in to help!\n\nBecome a PCB Design Superhero with AI!\n\nTraditionally, designing PCBs (printed circuit boards) is a slow, manual process that is prone to errors. However, Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming this process.\n\nFaster turnaround times: AI automates tedious tasks like placing components and wiring them up. Enhanced design quality: AI acts as a virtual inspector, analyzing designs for potential errors. Catching these mistakes early saves time and money by avoiding costly fixes later. Simplified rule adherence: AI simplifies rule adherence by automatically checking if your design follows them, reducing errors, and ensuring everything works as planned. Improved board performance: AI suggests ways to make the circuit board work better, use less power, manage heat consumption, and even last longer.\n\nOverall, AI is revolutionizing PCB design and translates to faster product development, reduced costs, and, ultimately, more reliable electronic devices.\n\n3 Ways AI Supercharges Your PCB Design Workflow\n\nDesigning those tiny circuits, the heart of electronic devices, can be time-consuming. But AI can help you create electronic designs faster and smarter.\n\nA. Automating the Tedious Stuff (Intelligent Automation)\n\nCreating complex PCBs is a time-consuming process. But with the help of AI (Artificial Intelligence), the process is a breeze. Here's how:\n\nComponent Placement: AI algorithms analyze the size and connectivity requirements of each component on your PCB. Based on this analysis, they recommend optimal placement locations, ensuring efficient use of space and facilitating proper signal routing. Routing Optimization: Connecting components with wires used to be slow and prone to mistakes. AI takes care of this by making sure the connections are safe and the signals travel clearly. This automatic wiring improves the functionality of the circuits. B. Making Your Design Flawless (Design Optimization and Error Reduction)\n\nAI is a super genius! It analyzes your PCB layout and identifies potential problems before they cause issues in the final product. AI can help you optimize your electronics design in various areas.\n\nSignal Integrity: Tiny electrical currents travel on your circuit board like data. AI checks these pathways to make sure the signals stay strong and clear. This keeps your circuit working properly and prevents it from weakening or getting distorted. Stable Power Distribution: Imagine every part on your circuit board needing the right amount of electricity to work well. AI analyzes the power supply network (the wiring that delivers electricity) and identifies potential problems like voltage drops (voltage dips) or uneven distribution. By catching these issues early on, AI ensures a steady and reliable flow of power to all components on the board. Error Checking: Imagine designing a perfect circuit board but encountering problems during manufacturing. AI helps avoid these issues by analyzing your design for potential errors, like components being in the wrong place or using the wrong materials. These AI checks are like catching typos before you print a document - they save you time and money by fixing problems early. There are even specialized AI tools called DRC (Design Rule-Checking) that automate this process, ensuring your design meets all the electrical and manufacturing guidelines. C. Learning from Every Design (Data-Driven Insights and Collaboration)\n\nAI goes beyond just completing tasks; it constantly learns and improves. Here's how it empowers your team of electronics designs.\n\nData-Driven Insights: AI takes a deep dive into past projects, analyzing successes, failures, and how well different designs performed. By finding patterns in this data, AI can recommend the best approaches and highlight potential problems for your future electronics designs. This lets you base your decisions on real-world results, not just educated guesses. Intelligent Component Management: Forget hunting for parts! AI creates a special library stocked with pre-tested components that have all the information you need. This saves you time searching and lets you choose reliable parts with confidence, making your design process smoother. Feedback Mechanisms: AI helps your design team learn from each other. It analyzes data and highlights potential issues, sparking discussions about how to fix them. This encourages everyone to share their knowledge, from past successes to tricky problems they encountered. By using real-world data, the team can make better decisions and keep learning together. The Future of PCB Design: Where AI Makes Things Awesome!\n\nThe capabilities of AI in PCB design are rapidly evolving, offering exciting new possibilities:\n\nGenerative Design: Imagine skipping the drawing board entirely! AI can explore tons of different circuit board layouts based on your needs and goals. This lets you see many possibilities quickly, potentially leading to even better designs and faster development. Sophisticated Design Assistants: AI-powered design assistants are becoming more advanced, offering real-time feedback and suggestions. AI assistants analyze your circuit board design in real time, pointing out potential problems and suggesting improvements. This lets you catch mistakes early and make your design even better right from the start. AR/VR Integration: Thanks to AI, the future of designing circuit boards is 3D! Imagine using special glasses or headsets to see your design in full detail, like it's right in front of you. This makes it easier to visualize and even work on your design together with your team in real time, helping you solve problems even faster. Self-healing PCBs: Imagine a PCB that can fix itself! Researchers are exploring AI-powered systems that can detect and address minor damage to PCB traces. This could revolutionize reliability and extend the lifespan of electronic devices. AI-driven Thermal Management: Heat is a major enemy of electronics. AI can become a thermal management whiz, analyzing heat distribution on your PCB and suggesting optimizations for cooling systems. This would lead to cooler-running devices with improved performance and longevity. Industry 4.0 Integration: As Industry 4.0 practices like smart factories and connected machines become more widespread, AI-powered PCB design will play a crucial role. Imagine AI seamlessly integrating with manufacturing processes, optimizing production lines, and identifying potential issues before they arise.\n\nBy automating tedious tasks, catching mistakes early, and even suggesting better designs, AI makes this process much faster and smoother. Get ready for a brighter future powered by smarter circuit boards!\n\nAI: The Future Engine of PCB Design\n\nAI is rapidly transforming PCB design. It's no longer science fiction but a powerful tool for creating better boards faster. AI is reshaping the entire design process by automating tasks, optimizing performance, and promoting collaboration. This not only saves time and money but also opens doors for even more innovative and powerful electronics in the future. Get ready for a brighter future powered by more competent circuit boards!\n\nAs AI continues to evolve, we can expect even more groundbreaking advancements. Imagine self-healing PCBs that fix themselves or AI-powered thermal management systems with innovative electronic designs! The possibilities are truly limitless.\n\nRelated Items:Artificial intelligence, tech Recommended for you Navigating the Future of Software Development: The Ashutosh Tripathi Journey Essential Mac AI technologies are enhancing the efficiency, accuracy, and profitability of financial operations. This post will delve into the various applications of AI in trading and investment, the benefits these advancements bring, and their impact on the financial industry.\n\n### Algorithmic Trading\n\nAI-driven algorithmic trading systems use complex algorithms to execute trades at optimal times, maximizing profits and minimizing risks. These systems analyze vast amounts of market data, identify patterns, and make split-second decisions, outperforming human traders in speed and accuracy.\n\n### High-Frequency Trading\n\nAI enhances high-frequency trading (HFT) by processing and executing a large number of trades in fractions of a second. By leveraging machine learning and predictive analytics, AI systems can capitalize on minute price discrepancies, leading to significant profits.\n\n### Robo-Advisors\n\nAI-powered robo-advisors provide automated, personalized investment advice based on individual risk tolerance, financial goals, and market conditions. These advisors use algorithms to create and manage diversified portfolios, making investment accessible to a broader audience.\n\n### Predictive Analytics\n\nAI uses predictive analytics to forecast market trends and asset performance. By analyzing historical data, economic indicators, and market sentiment, AI systems can predict future price movements and inform investment strategies.\n\n### Risk Management\n\nAI improves risk management by identifying and mitigating potential risks in real-time. AI systems can analyze market volatility, detect anomalies, and provide early warnings, enabling financial institutions to take proactive measures to protect their investments.\n\n### Fraud Detection\n\nAI-driven fraud detection systems monitor transactions for suspicious activity, using machine learning algorithms to identify patterns indicative of fraud. These systems enhance the security of financial transactions and protect clients' assets.\n\n### Advanced Portfolio Management\n\nAI will continue to advance portfolio management by integrating more complex data sources and refining predictive models. This will enable more precise asset allocation and risk assessment, leading to better investment outcomes.\n\n### Ethical AI\n\nAs AI becomes more integral to finance, ethical considerations will play a crucial role. Ensuring transparency, fairness, and accountability in AI-driven financial systems will be essential to maintaining trust and compliance.\n\nAI is transforming the financial sector by automating trading and investment decisions, enhancing risk management, and improving operational efficiency. From algorithmic trading and robo-advisors to predictive analytics and fraud detection, AI technologies are revolutionizing the way financial services are delivered. {"uri": "2024-07-426772111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "06:49:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T06:49:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T06:49:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.newsday.co.zw/theindependent/opinion/article/200029777/slow-ai-penetration-in-africa", "title": "Slow AI penetration in Africa", "body": "However, the main challenge remains that Southern Africa still lacks the digital infrastructure to ensure that it enjoys this all important technology.\n\nTHE world is currently gripped by the phenomenon of Artificial Intelligence (AI) but Southern Africa is yet to meaningfully enjoy this wonder.\n\nMost importantly is that the Southern African populace is merely a beneficiary of AI without having invented or given an input in the engineering technology that ushered Artificial Intelligence (AI).\n\nHowever, the main challenge remains that Southern Africa still lacks the digital infrastructure to ensure that it enjoys this all important technology. It is not a lie that AI is marginally enjoyed in Southern African urban areas with a greater majority in the high density, farming and rural communities not enjoying this important communication tool.\n\nA Southern African country that is somehow prepared in terms of adopting AI is South Africa that has at least among other things achieved the electrification of all its communities including the rural areas. Electricity is one of the key aspects that is part of the Digital Infrastructure that is critical to powering computers.\n\nPenetration of AI in Southern Africa will be expected to be employed in all forms of productive processes like manufacturing, education, hospitality, agriculture, communication and so on.\n\nTo prove this case, PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) consulting firm estimates the global economic impact of AI to be around US $15,7 trillion by 2030, the report indicates that of this figure US$6,6 trillion is likely to come from increased productivity and US$9,1 trillion is likely to come from consumption side effects.\n\nIn light of this, Africa and Southern Africa in particular should be a beneficiary of the AI windfall expected by 2030 so as to improve its GDP as the World Bank recorded that in 2023 sub Saharan African merely recorded a GDP of 2,03 trillion.\n\nIf the Southern African countries are to benefit in Agricultural production, aspects such as monitoring soil, crop health, conduct predictive analysis for pest and disease management and automating machinery enhances farming operations, efficiency and sustainability.\n\nBe that as it may, the challenge remains that AI penetration in Southern Africa is very slow, especially in high density, rural and marginalised communities. As these communities lack the necessary investments in issues like digital infrastructure, automated machinery to carry out the Agricultural activities as well as knowledge to grasp AI issues.\n\nKnowledge on AI is truly one aspect that acts against quicker penetration of this all important ecosystem in both rural and marginalised communities in Southern Africa.\n\nAccording to the Unesco-data only around three out of every 100 graduates across Sub-Saharan Africa earn a degree in the STEM field, severely constraining the AI pipeline.\n\nConsidering this, Southern African countries are encouraged to innovate by way of creating public-private partnerships for strengthening AI circular and reskilling workforce, akin to Egypt's Knowledge City AI programme and Google's AI Research Center in Ghana.\n\nWhat is clear is that in Southern Africa urban schools particularly those for the haves can afford to teach STEM with easy as some subjects under STEM requires well equipped laboratories. This impacts negatively on equal proliferation of AI knowledge in communities, due to uneven STEM knowledge access.\n\nThe greatest challenge is that even though innovation is a powerful force that shapes economies and societies, yet it often tends to favour already developed communities, perpetuating divisions between the privileged and the marginalised.\n\nThis is despite the claims of addressing societal challenges, many innovators inadvertently neglect the needs of the most vulnerable population, focusing on those communities that can afford services.\n\nThere is really need to uplift the lives of the underprivileged as their lives matter even on issues of AI adoption. The other vital cog not to forget is the evident rural-urban divide prevalent in most Southern African countries. A lot of rural community dwellers do not own AI compatible gadgets like smartphones, computers connected to the internet and mostly rural areas in Southern African nations do not have electricity.\n\nComputer literacy is another big challenge even to rural students.\n\nTherefore, Southern African countries need to play a pivotal role in addressing the disparities attendant to access to AI in various communities of their countries, if AI discussions are meant to be treated seriously or be considered as something that benefit all Southern African communities.\n\nThis takes us to the issue of policy formulation. At the legislative front Southern African parliaments need to promote popular participation when drafting rules, regulations, standards, policies and legislation that govern AI.\n\nIn other words, there is need for a bottom up approach in the making of laws that govern the use of AI, as the laws have serious implications on their day-to-day survival of the Southern African people. This also takes cognisance of the fact that AI is going to drive most issues around production and education, including service delivery.\n\nHence the policies of this nature need to be holistic in nature to make sure that all persons understand the legislation enacted to support AI activities in each nation.\n\nIn other words, duty bearers like parliamentarians need a lot of orientation to ensure that they understand the essence and importance of AI laws in every country's development.\n\nThis also goes with members of the executive like cabinet ministers, who more often than not originate Bills that are debated in parliament.\n\nThey should receive adequate knowledge about AI through their technical teams like permanent secretaries or directors-general.\n\nAI has become so important as all life is now heading towards it, be it in farming, education, hospitality industry, health and many other aspects of life.\n\nIn view of this, Southern African countries need to be prepared for this happening with informed preparedness. The regional trade like the Southern Africa and connectivity project must also be equipped with AI tools to improve business efficiency, automating manual tasks, enhance data analytics, and so on.\n\nAI is an important game-changer in ensuring business efficacy, automating manual tasks and improving health delivery systems across the world and Southern Africa in particular.\n\nHowever, Southern Africa needs to put in place legislative and economic strategies that can see AI dividends realised even by marginalised communities by way of penetration in all communities, of their {"uri": "8233640916", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:03:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:03:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T14:03:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.gamespace.com/all-articles/news/the-role-of-artificial-intelligence-in-modern-video-games/", "title": "The Role of Artificial Intelligence in Modern Video Games - GameSpace.com", "body": "Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become a transformative force in modern video games, reshaping game development, enhancing player experiences, and revolutionizing competitive gaming dynamics. In recent years, AI's integration into gaming has expanded beyond mere automation, becoming a cornerstone of innovation and creativity in the industry. Game developers now rely on AI algorithms not just for procedural generation of environments and characters but also for dynamic adaptation based on player choices, creating truly interactive and immersive worlds that evolve with each gaming session.\n\nThe integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into gaming as a fundamental mechanic has evolved significantly over the past decades. Initially employed for basic opponent behaviors and procedural generation, AI in gaming has advanced to encompass complex decision-making processes, adaptive gameplay mechanics, and realistic NPC interactions.\n\nEarly uses of AI in games focused on creating predictable patterns for enemies or optimizing resource management within game environments. As computing power and AI algorithms improved, developers began harnessing AI to enhance player immersion through dynamic storytelling, personalized gameplay experiences, and sophisticated opponent AI that adapts to player strategies in real-time. In parallel, AI has also found its place in areas like League of Legends betting, where predictive algorithms analyze gameplay and player statistics to inform betting strategies.\n\nToday, AI serves as a cornerstone in modern game design, powering everything from realistic physics engines to AI-driven procedural content generation in expansive virtual worlds. Its role continues to expand, shaping the future of gaming by enabling new levels of interactivity, challenge, and narrative depth that redefine what players can expect from interactive entertainment.\n\nThe usage of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in League of Legends tournaments represents a cutting-edge approach to enhancing gameplay analysis and strategy. AI algorithms are employed to dissect vast amounts of game data, including player statistics, match histories, and real-time gameplay metrics. This analytical power enables coaches and analysts to identify trends, optimize team strategies, and predict opponent movements with unprecedented accuracy.\n\nAI also plays a crucial role in enhancing broadcasting and viewer experience by providing real-time insights, highlighting key moments, and generating interactive visualizations that offer deeper insights into player decision-making and team dynamics. As AI continues to evolve, its integration into LoL tournaments promises to revolutionize how teams prepare, compete, and engage with audiences, pushing the boundaries of competitive gaming to new heights.\n\nBeyond development, AI significantly enhances player experiences by personalizing gameplay and improving immersion. Adaptive AI algorithms analyze player behaviors in real-time, adjusting game difficulty dynamically to match individual skill levels and play styles. This not only ensures that players are consistently challenged but also prevents frustration by adapting the gameplay experience to their evolving abilities. Moreover, AI-driven NPCs exhibit human-like behaviors and emotions, creating deeper connections and enhancing storytelling in ways that resonate emotionally with players, fostering empathy and investment in game narratives.\n\nIn esports, AI has emerged as a game-changer, influencing competitive dynamics and strategy. AI-driven analytics provide coaches and players with invaluable insights into gameplay patterns and opponent strategies, offering teams a competitive advantage. These analytics help teams optimize their training regimes, refine strategies, and anticipate opponent moves with precision. Matchmaking algorithms powered by AI enhance the fairness and integrity of esports competitions, ensuring balanced matchups that challenge players to continually improve their skills, thereby driving the evolution of professional gaming leagues worldwide.\n\nHowever, the integration of AI in gaming also raises ethical considerations and technical challenges that require careful consideration. Issues such as AI bias in character design and gameplay mechanics, concerns over data privacy related to player profiling, and the ethical implications of AI-controlled game environments necessitate robust ethical guidelines and regulatory frameworks. Balancing innovation with ethical considerations is crucial to fostering a sustainable and inclusive gaming ecosystem that respects player rights, promotes diversity, and safeguards against unintended consequences of AI implementation in games.\n\nLooking forward, AI continues to push the boundaries of gaming innovation. Advances in machine learning and neural networks promise even more sophisticated AI behaviors and dynamic procedural content generation. Future games will likely feature AI systems capable of learning from player interactions in real-time, adapting game worlds and narratives in ways that are uniquely tailored to individual players. Moreover, the fusion of AI with emerging technologies like virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) opens new frontiers for immersive gaming experiences, blurring the lines between virtual worlds and reality itself and offering players unprecedented levels of immersion and interactivity.\n\nIn conclusion, AI stands as a cornerstone of modern video games, transforming every facet from development and player interaction to competitive gaming and ethical considerations. As AI technologies evolve, so too will their impact on the gaming industry, shaping the future of interactive entertainment in ways previously unimaginable. Embracing AI responsibly promises a future where gaming not only entertains but also inspires, challenges, and connects players across the globe, driving forward a new era of innovation and creativity in gaming that is both exciting and ethically mindful of its societal impact.", "source": {"uri": "gamespace.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GameSpace.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8232509579", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "22:11:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T22:11:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T22:11:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.fortinet.com/blog/industry-trends/fortinet-contributes-to-world-economic-forum-ai-and-cyber-initiative", "title": "Fortinet Contributes to the World Economic Forum's AI and Cyber Initiative | Fortinet Blog", "body": "Just as our digital adversaries work together to advance their attack methods, no single organization alone can successfully disrupt cybercrime at scale. Fortinet has a long history of collaborating with global experts across various sectors, pursuing a shared goal of making our digital world more secure. We regularly work with public and private organizations to advance our collective cyber resiliency through initiatives that encourage knowledge and threat intelligence sharing.\n\nOne such example is our ongoing engagement with the World Economic Forum. Fortinet is a founding member of the World Economic Forum's Centre for Cybersecurity, founded in 2018, and is also a charter member of the Cybercrime Atlas, a joint initiative launched by the organization's Partnership Against Cybercrime project. Through these efforts and more, Fortinet addresses critical, timely cybersecurity challenges impacting entities around the globe, ranging from the ongoing cybersecurity talent shortage to the necessary evolution of risk management strategies as new technologies come to market.\n\nOrganizations are increasingly adopting new technologies and many are harnessing AI to enhance nearly all aspects of their operations. According to a recent McKinsey Global Survey, 65% of business leaders say their companies regularly use generative AI. Yet the adoption of any new technology inevitably brings with it benefits and risks. As organizations take greater advantage of AI-driven offerings, their attack surfaces are expanding as a result.\n\nLast year, leaders engaged with the World Economic Forum's Centre for Cybersecurity raised the need for organizations globally to better understand the cybersecurity implications of using AI technologies and gain clear direction on how to securely adopt these offerings. As a result, the World Economic Forum launched its AI and Cyber Initiative in the spring of 2024 to develop guidance for organizations to manage the complex cyber risks associated with the adoption of these technologies.\n\nThe AI and Cyber Initiative is a collaboration between the World Economic Forum's Centre for Cybersecurity, the Global Cyber Security Capacity Centre at the University of Oxford, various business partners, government and international organizations, and civil society and alliances. Together, the group will explore the practical and exploitable dangers of AI. This includes examining real-world model poisoning methods, data lineage models, data validation for input and output to AI models, and the privacy and sensitivity concerns around AI regarding linking potentially identifiable information back to individuals.\n\nAs an inaugural member of this initiative, Fortinet brings real-world experience to the group, offering insights into how threat actors harness AI technologies to create attacks and exploits. Fortinet provides unique insights from FortiGuard Labs, our elite threat research organization, assessing thousands of threat data artifacts and determining how AI is being used on the offensive side and providing insights into using AI to defend against attack techniques.\n\nThe FortiGuard Labs team keeps a pulse on threat actor activity and monitors the tools, techniques, and tactics attackers use to infiltrate organizations. This enables us to showcase how organizations can harness AI and ML models to protect against specific threats and how AI can assist with increasing the efficiency and efficacy of cyber protections.\n\nA virtual kickoff for the AI and Cyber Initiative occurred in April, bringing together 45 cybersecurity and AI leaders from around the world. The session introduced the effort to the community and was followed by breakout sessions in which leaders discussed the cyber risks and associated mitigation measures stemming from the implementation of AI.\n\nLast month, I was thrilled to continue these important conversations on behalf of Fortinet and attend the Cyber Leaders Roundtable, the first in-person meeting for the AI and Cyber Initiative held in Oxford, United Kingdom. More than 30 of the initiative participants from public, private, and civil society organizations, as well as academia, came together in Oxford to share their insights, experiences, and key priorities related to the adoption of AI technologies.\n\nThis event fostered multistakeholder dialogues between cyber leaders on cyber resilience and AI. It brought together the communities from the AI and Cyber initiative and the Cyber Resilience Blueprint initiative to understand cyber resilience tradecrafts. We discussed the controls, behaviors, and messages that matter, advanced the understanding of the risk scenarios related to the implementation and use of AI, and examined the impacts of the innovative and changing era of AI in cyber resilience. Fortinet played an active role at the Cyber Leaders Roundtable on sharing how to use current technologies to protect against AI attacks. This included discussing AI firewalls, testing AI models, reviewing AI controls, integrating data loss prevention technologies, and showcasing the role of the human element and the dangers of AI models.\n\nUnderstanding and accounting for the cyber risks associated with new technologies is a crucial part of effectively managing every organization's risks. At the recent roundtable, we discussed that businesses need to be resilient to cyber incidents to ensure minimum impact on operations, and that cyber resilience involves a toolbox of methods to harden the environment, detect and respond to attacks, and ensure business resilience in the face of malicious cyberattacks and accidental cyber failures. It also involves learning from incidents and evolving to stronger postures.\n\nThe discussions and guidance resulting from the AI and Cyber Initiative will offer public and private sector institutions valuable insight into how to balance business growth with ongoing cyber resiliency. Fortinet and FortiGuard Labs are committed to continuing our research on how threat actors exploit AI vulnerabilities. Using continuous threat intelligence collection, threat research capabilities, breach research, and incident response cases, Fortinet is keeping a pulse on how attackers are evolving and has committed to the World Economic Forum to discuss, research, and share its insights into the dangers of AI exploitation and how organizations can effectively protect against those threats.", "source": {"uri": "label": "dmoz/Society/Work", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Activism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Activism", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Future", "label": "dmoz/Society/Future", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Activism/In_Daily_Life", "label": "dmoz/Society/Activism/In Daily Life", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Future/Organizations", "label": "dmoz/Society/Future/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 73}], "image": "https://www.fortinet.com/content/dam/fortinet-blog/article-heros/wef-ai-hero.png", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9737001", "eventUri": "eng-9737001", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1137254901960785, "wgt": 133, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8234085710", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:01:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:01:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:01:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/07/19/california-becomes-a-battleground-for-ai-bills-as-trump-plans-to-curb-regulation/", "title": "California becomes a battleground for AI bills as Trump plans to curb regulation", "body": "California State Sen. Scott Wiener, D-San Francisco, has proposed a measure that would force the biggest and best-funded companies to test their AI for \"catastrophic\" risks before releasing it to the public. Rich Pedroncelli/Associated Press, file\n\nSAN FRANCISCO - Republican delegates meeting this week in Milwaukee pledged to roll back federal restrictions on artificial intelligence, while other allies of former President Donald Trump laid plans for \"Manhattan Projects\" to boost military AI.\n\nBut in California, the state's Democratic-controlled Legislature is moving in the opposite direction, debating a proposal that would force the biggest and best-funded companies to test their AI for \"catastrophic\" risks before releasing it to the public.\n\nThe measure, written by Scott Wiener, a Democratic state senator from San Francisco, has drawn howls from tech industry leaders, who argue it would scare off technologists aiming to build AI tools in the state and add bureaucratic busywork that might box out scrappy startups.\n\nOpponents of the bill have claimed it could even result in developers being sent to jail if their tech is used to harm people, something Wiener has vociferously denied.\n\nAfter the bill was approved by a California Senate committee earlier this month, Google's head of AI and emerging tech policy, Alice Friend, wrote a letter to the chairman arguing that its provisions are \"not technically feasible\" and \"would punish developers even if they have acted responsibly.\"\n\nWiener says the law is necessary to forestall the most extreme potential risks of AI and instill trust in the technology. Its passage is urgent, he said, in light of Republican commitments to undo a 2023 executive order that uses the Defense Production Act to require AI companies to share information about safety testing with the government.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"This action by Trump makes it all the more important for California to act to promote robust AI innovation,\" Wiener said on the social media site X last week.\n\nThe bill has established Sacramento as ground zero for the battle over government regulation of AI. It is also shedding light on the limits of Silicon Valley's enthusiasm for government oversight, even as key leaders such as OpenAI CEO Sam Altman publicly urge policymakers to act.\n\nBy mandating previously voluntary commitments, Wiener's bill has gone further than tech leaders are willing to accept, said Nicol Turner Lee, director of the Center for Technology Innovation at the Brookings Institution.\n\nIt is \"suggesting that Big Tech needs to be much more accountable,\" Lee said, \"and that was not well received among industry.\"\n\nDylan Hoffman, TechNet's executive director for California and the Southwest, said Friend's letter - along with letters from Meta and Microsoft before it - show the \"weight and importance\" the companies place on the measure.\n\n\"It's a pretty extraordinary step for them ... to step out from behind the trade association and put their name on the letter,\" he said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSpokespeople for Google, OpenAI and Meta declined to comment.\n\n\"Microsoft has not taken a position on the bill and will continue to maintain support for federal legislation as the primary means to regulate the issues it addresses,\" said Robyn Hines, senior director of government affairs at Microsoft.\n\nEven before Wiener unveiled his bill in February, California had established itself as the nation's de facto tech legislature. After years of debate in Congress, California passed the country's most wide-ranging digital privacy law in 2018. And the state's Department of Motor Vehicles has become a key regulator of autonomous vehicles.\n\nOn AI, President Biden's executive order in October marked Washington's most extensive effort to regulate the booming technology. But Republicans have announced plans to repeal the order if Trump wins Nov. 5, leaving states to carry the flag for stricter AI regulation.\n\nMore than 450 bills involving AI have been active in legislative sessions in state capitals across the nation this year, according to TechNet, an industry trade association whose members include OpenAI and Google. More than 45 are pending in California, though many have been abandoned or held up in committee.\n\nBut Wiener's bill is the most prominent and controversial of the batch. It would require any AI company deploying a certain amount of computing power to test whether its models could lead to \"catastrophic\" risks, such as helping people develop chemical or biological weapons, hacking into key infrastructure, or blacking out power grids. The companies would submit safety reports to a new government office, the Frontier Model Division, which would have the power to update which AI models are covered by the law - something opponents say could introduce even more uncertainty.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe bill tasks the government with creating a cloud computing system to be used by researchers and startups, allowing them to develop AI without having to rely on the massive expense of Big Tech cloud companies.\n\nDan Hendrycks, founder of the nonprofit Center for AI Safety, consulted on the bill. Last year, he organized an open letter signed by prominent AI researchers and executives arguing that AI could be as dangerous to humanity as nuclear war and pandemics.\n\nOthers say such risks are overblown and unlikely to materialize for years, if ever. And skeptics of the bill point out that even if such risks were imminent, there is no standard way to test for them.\n\n\"Size is the wrong metric,\" said Oren Etzioni, an AI researcher and founder of the AI deepfake detection nonprofit TrueMedia.org. \"We could have models that this doesn't touch but are much more potentially dangerous.\"\n\nThe focus on \"catastrophic\" risks has also frustrated some AI researchers who say there are more tangible harms from AI, such as injecting racist and sexist bias into tech tools and providing another venue for people's private data to be vacuumed up by tech companies - issues that other bills moving through the California Legislature aim to tackle.\n\nThe bill's focus on catastrophic risks even led Meta's head of AI, Yann LeCun, to call Hendrycks an \"apocalyptic cult guru.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"The idea that taking societal-scale risks from AI seriously makes one an 'apocalyptic cult guru' is absurd,\" Hendrycks replied.\n\nHendrycks recently launched a company called Gray Swan, which builds software to assess the safety and security of AI models. On Thursday, tech news site Pirate Wires published a containing allegations that the company represents a conflict of interest for Hendrycks, because it might win business helping companies comply with the AI law if it is passed.\n\n\"Critics have accused me of an elaborate scheme to make money, when I fact I've spent my professional career working to advance AI safety issues,\" Hendrycks said. \"I disclosed what is a theoretical conflict of interest as soon as I was able, and whatever I stand to gain from this tiny startup is a minuscule fraction of the economic stakes driving the behavior of those who oppose the bill.\"\n\nAlthough Hendrycks has lately been criticized by some Silicon Valley denizens, leaders of the companies opposing the law have issued similar warnings about the danger of powerful AI models. Senior AI executives from Google, Microsoft and OpenAI signed the letter that Hendrycks' group circulated in May last year warning that humanity faced a \"risk of extinction from AI.\" At a congressional hearing in the same month, Altman said that AI could \"cause significant harm to the world.\"\n\nOpenAI also joined last year with fellow startup Anthropic, Google and other tech companies to start an industry group to develop safety standards for new and powerful AI models. Last week, tech trade association ITI, whose members include Google and Meta, released a set of best practices for \"high-risk AI systems\" that include proactive testing.\n\nStill, those same companies are pushing back on the idea of writing commitments into law.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn a June 20 letter organized by startup incubator Y Combinator, founders railed against placing extra scrutiny on projects that use a large amount of computing power.\n\n\"Such specific metrics may not adequately capture the capabilities or risks associated with future models,\" the letter said. \"It is crucial to avoid over-regulating AI.\"\n\nStartup leaders also are concerned that the bill would make it harder for companies to develop and release \"open-source\" technology, which is available for anyone to use and change. In a March post on X, now-Republican vice presidential candidate J.D. Vance described open source as key to building models free of the political bias of OpenAI and Google's tech.\n\nWiener has altered the bill in response to industry feedback and criticism, including by stipulating that open-source developers aren't responsible for safety problems that emerge from third parties changing their tech. Industry critics say those tweaks aren't enough.\n\nMeanwhile, other bills working their way through the California Legislature have drawn less notice from the tech industry.\n\nAssemblymember Rebecca Bauer-Kahan, a Democrat who represents a suburban swath of the eastern Bay Area, wrote several AI bills moving through the chamber, including one requiring companies to test AI models for biases. Another of her bills would ban developers from using the personal information of children to train their AI models without parental consent, potentially challenging the tech industry practice of scraping training data from websites.\n\nAI bills introduced by other California legislators would require tech companies to release summaries describing the data used to develop AI models, create tools to detect AI-generated content, and apply digital watermarks to make AI-generated content identifiable - as some companies, including Google, have already attempted.\n\n\"We would love for the federal government to take a lead here,\" Bauer-Kahan said. \"But in the absence of them functioning and passing laws like this, Sacramento feels the need to step up.\"\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\n\" Previous\n\nBritish Open: Lowry emerges from chaos with two-stroke lead\n\nNext \"\n\nBlinken points to wider pledges to support Ukraine in case U.S. backs {"uri": "8232440975", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "20:59:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T20:59:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T20:59:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.myjoyonline.com/indabax-ghana-promotes-correct-and-positive-use-of-ai-through-summit/", "title": "IndabaX Ghana promotes correct and positive use of AI through summit - MyJoyOnline", "body": "The wrong, ignorant and inappropriate use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) by Ghanaian youth could stall its positive potential especially when it comes to the development of human capital for a digital future.\n\nThis could lead to unhealthy over-reliance, ethical breaches, and data privacy risks that could cause unintended harm to others, and hinder critical and creative thinking.\n\nIndabaX Ghana summit has assembled 600 enthusiastic youth to advance the trance of democratizing data science literacy and fostering supportive communities across the country.\n\nThe unsafe and unfamiliar usage of artificial intelligence tools in sectors of education, technology, and business are a growing concern.\n\nA major factor contributing to this is the little to no knowledge on positive potentials of AI.\n\nThe IndabaX Ghana 2024 summit in Kumasi, has gathered technology enthusiasts under the theme, \"Unleashing the potential of AI through grassroots engagement.\"\n\nThrough diverse sessions, including a research showcase, industry and networking opportunities, and hands-on workshops, the summit aims to bridge the knowledge gap and equip participants with practical skills in AI.\n\nThe three-day event has assembled Ghanaian youth in a stimulating discussion on Data Science, Machine Learning, and Artificial Intelligence (AI).\n\nExecutive Chair of the Conference Steering Committee, Delali Agbenyegah, said the grassroot engagement of youth will facilitate positive awareness of the potentials of Artificial Intelligence.\n\n\"The mission is to boost capacity and create awareness about AI and how young people can take advantage of Artificial Intelligence in sectors and improve our systems. Our training is focused on responsible AI and it is important to involve the young people.\n\n\"Knowledge about AI is centralized in the Western world. So we are bringing people to learn whilst we plant a seed of possibilities of AI in them. This will ensure that we are developing systems, because these young people will fill these systems,\" he said.\n\nThe summit assembled technology experts, and data scientists across the world to engage and mentor the enthusiastic participants.\n\nAssociate Professor, Responsible Al Lab, KNUST, Prof. Jerry John Kponyo said the country should plan strategically for AI adoption.\n\n\"New jobs are going to be created as a result of AI. And it is affecting key areas like energy, agriculture, etc. What it means is that we should be able to strategically position ourselves in a way that we could maximize the benefits of AI.\n\n\"Criticisms are about the negative effects of AI. Which is why there is a responsible AI Lab. We are hoping to enhance the positives to be able to guard against the negatives,\" he said.\n\nVice Chancellor, Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST), Prof Mrs Rita Akosua Dickson disclosed that the university is preparing to build capacity for KNUST staff on AI.\n\n\"The university is preparing to organize a summer school for all staff on AI. The whole concept is that at the end of the day, it is very key that no one is left behind.\n\n\"We must build the capacity of not just students, but staff and everyone who matters. Whilst we do that, responsible usage of AI must be championed. Which is why this summit matters,\" she said.\n\nThe IndabaX Ghana 2024 summit is in partnership with KNUST Responsible AI Lab, Deep Learning Indaba, Google, NVIDIA, GIZ Digital, Transformation Center and FAIR Forward, Maverick, Research, Aya Data, WiMLDS Accra, Mozilla, MTN Ghana, and Wave-2 Analytics.\n\nThis year's conference marks the 5th anniversary of IndabaX Ghana.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8232063481", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "15:42:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T15:42:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T15:41:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=e47a4cf1-22b3-4d6d-b030-fcf32e4f56bc", "title": "EU AI Act Enters into Force: Key Compliance Dates for Stakeholders", "body": "The long-anticipated AI Act was published in the Official Journal of the European Union on 12 July 2024 and will enter into force on 1 August 2024.\n\nLaying down harmonised rules on the regulation of artificial intelligence across all EU Member States, there are important compliance deadlines of which all stakeholders should be aware:\n\nGeneral Applicability after 24 Months - 2 August 2026\n\nThe AI Act provides for a 24-month transitional period, to allow time for delegated legislation, guidelines, and standards to be drafted and published across all Member States. Most general provisions of the Act will apply from 2 August 2026, with some exceptions outlined below.\n\nProhibited Practices Provisions - Applicability after 6 Months - 2 February 2025\n\nArticle 5 of the AI Act outlines 'prohibited practices' which become unlawful on 2 February 2025. These include exploitative or manipulative AI tools that alter human behaviour in a harmful way, social scoring techniques, the creation of facial recognition databases through untargeted scraping of images online or from CCTV, emotional recognition AI tools, as well as the use of biometric identification systems based on highly sensitive characteristics, among others.\n\nGeneral Purpose AI Models, Governance and Sanctions Provisions - Applicability after 12 Months - 2 August 2025\n\n2 August 2025 marks the applicability of Chapter V relating to general purpose AI models, with obligations around classification, and procedure, as well as additional obligations placed on providers of general-purpose AI models which fall under a 'systemic risk' category.\n\nException - Applicability for Certain High-Risk AI Systems after 36 Months - 2 August 2027\n\nAn exception to the general date of application applies to certain high-risk AI products subject to harmonising EU legislation listed in Annex I of the Act, or AI systems that are a safety component of such products that require a third-party conformity assessment in advance of being placed on the market. AI systems that fall within this category have an additional 12 months from the date of general applicability, with full compliance required by 2 August 2027.\n\nGrandfathering Provisions - Differing Timelines\n\nThere are a number of grandfathering provisions under the AI Act. Those of most general application relate to \"high risk\" AI systems in use prior to 2 August 2026. Such \"high-risk\" AI systems are not subject to the AI Act unless they are subject to \"significant changes in their design\", or if they are used by public authorities (in which case they must comply by 2 August 2030).\n\nConclusion\n\nThe risk-based approach of the AI Act brings with it a complex set of deadlines, obligations and provisions which have significant consequences in the event of non-compliance. It is expected and hoped that guidance will be issued in the coming months for stakeholders.", "source": {"uri": "lexology.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Lexology"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8233868211", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "16:45:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T16:45:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T16:44:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/corneliawalther/2024/07/19/how-ai-can-compensate-for-age-related-cognitive-decline/", "title": "How AI Can Compensate For Age-Related Cognitive Decline", "body": "The global population aged 60 and older is projected to nearly double, from 12% to 22%, between 2015 and 2050, according to the World Health Organization. This demographic shift brings with it concerns about cognitive decline, including memory loss and reduced problem-solving abilities, as well as physical decline such as reduced mobility and dexterity.\n\nCognitive aging is a natural process that affects everyone, albeit to varying degrees. It typically involves declines in processing speed, attention, and memory. These changes can begin as early as our 30s, with more pronounced effects in our 60s and beyond as shown by a 2022 study published in Nature Aging. However, it's crucial to note that cognitive aging is not synonymous with dementia or Alzheimer's disease -- it's a normal part of aging that can be managed and, in some cases, partially mitigated.\n\nWhilst there is abundant worry about artificial intelligence, including the fact that it is triggering a wave of destillier, upskilling and reskilling at work. It also has the potential to address both cognitive and physical aspects of aging through various innovative solutions. The key question is how we can leverage AI to age gracefully and maintain our cognitive abilities and effectiveness as we are traveling the journey of life and living well into the second half of it. AI may serve as a companion tool to explore and discover unknown strengths that had been dormant because we didn't have the opportunity to curate and share them. This time has come.\n\nArtificial Intelligence offers promising avenues to support cognitive function in aging individuals. Here are some key areas where AI is making a difference:\n\nMemory Enhancement: AI-powered digital assistants can serve as external memory banks, providing reminders for appointments, medication schedules, and important dates. Older adults can use digital health interventions, including AI-assisted reminders such as Google Assistant or Amazon Alexa, to help them adhere to medication schedules.\n\nDecision Support: Complex decision-making can become more challenging with age. AI systems like IBM Watson and Google Cloud's AI can analyze vast amounts of data and provide summarized insights, helping older leaders make informed decisions more efficiently.\n\nSpeech and Language Processing: AI tools like Otter.ai and Fireflies.ai can transcribe and summarize conversations in real-time, helping individuals keep track of important points in meetings or discussions.\n\nCognitive Training: AI-driven brain-training apps such as Lumosity and Elevate provide personalized exercises targeting specific cognitive domains, potentially slowing cognitive decline. Computerized cognitive training, which often incorporates AI algorithms, also shows promise in improving brain function in healthy older adults.\n\nBeyond cognitive support, AI is helping to detect and manage age-related neurodegenerative diseases early. For Parkinson's disease, AI algorithms analyzing voice recordings have shown promise in detecting early signs of the condition. They can identify subtle voice changes indicative of early-stage Parkinson's with an accuracy of over 87%, according to research.\n\nIn the realm of Alzheimer's disease, AI is revolutionizing early diagnosis by analyzing images. Since 2023, researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital have been using AI models capable of predicting Alzheimer's disease from a single brain MRI scan with 98% accuracy. These advancements in early detection could significantly improve treatment outcomes and quality of life for millions of aging individuals.\n\nThe 2024 US Presidential elections have brought the question of age-related decline to the forefront. This serves as a reminder that time is passing for all of us, and that AI could help to optimize what we make of the remainder.\n\nAs we explore the potential of AI to support aging individuals, especially those in positions of power, several ethical considerations arise:\n\nTransparency: There's a need for openness about the use of AI assistive technologies, particularly in roles that impact public policy and national security.\n\nAgency and Autonomy: It's crucial to ensure that AI remains a supportive tool rather than a replacement for human judgment and decision-making.\n\nPrivacy: The use of AI to monitor cognitive function, including the expansion of neuroscience assets such as brain chips as the one developed by Neuralink raises important privacy concerns that must be carefully addressed.\n\nFor professionals looking to leverage AI to support cognitive function as they age, consider the following strategies:\n\nEmbrace Digital Assistants: Start integrating AI-powered assistants such as Siri or Alexa into your daily routine for scheduling, reminders, and information management.\n\nUse AI to Process Information: Leverage AI tools like ChatGTP or Gemini to summarize lengthy reports or articles, helping you stay informed without cognitive overload. Zoom and Teams offer automated meeting notes.\n\nEngage in AI-Driven Cognitive Training: Incorporate personalized brain-training apps like Headspace into your routine to nurture your overall mindfulness and platforms such as Lumosity to curate specific cognitive skills.\n\nConsider AI Writing Assistants: Tools like GPT-based writing aids can help maintain writing quality and efficiency, particularly useful for those experiencing changes in language processing.\n\nStay Informed and Adaptable: Keep abreast of new AI technologies overall, especially those designed to support cognitive function and explore with their incorporation into your own workflow. Resources such as AI-focused newsletters or Blogs like Oneusefulthing, as well as industry conferences can be valuable for staying updated.\n\nUse AI to explore uncharted territory within yourself. AI may help you to identify strengths that you always had but never got a chance to reveal. Could generative artificial technologies serve to manifest your dormant creativity?\n\nUltimately what matters most is for each of us to remain acutely aware that AI is a means to an end, not an end in itself. It is up to us to decide how and why it can serve us - as a person, and as a professional - to be and become our own best selves.\n\nAI cannot halt the aging process, but it offers useful tools to compensate for age-related cognitive changes and detect potential health issues early. But further and beyond - it can serve us to unleash our latent potential to create.\n\nBy thoughtfully integrating new technologies into our personal and professional lives, we can potentially extend our productive years and remain not only effective but unique in demanding roles well into later life. As we move forward, it is up to us to balance the benefits of these technologies with ethical considerations, ensuring that AI is a tool for empowerment rather than a crutch to depend on.\n\nIt is a slippery slope from using, to over-using to trusting to relying on AI. We choose at which stage of this process we stop.", "source": {"uri": "forbes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Forbes"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8233868210", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "16:45:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T16:45:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T16:44:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/digital-assets/2024/07/19/4-ways-ai-is-driving-mainstream-defi-adoption/", "title": "4 Ways AI Is Driving Mainstream DeFi Adoption", "body": "AI and blockchain might appear to be polar opposites. Blockchain technology is deterministic, transparent, and open to everyone, with every transaction recorded immutably on a public ledger. It also has a steep learning curve, requiring users to understand complex protocols.\n\nOn the other hand, AI often functions as a \"black box,\" making decisions based on model parameters and learning data sets, providing probabilistic rather than strictly predictable answers. What unites them, however, is that both technologies have become buzzwords in recent years - venture capital funds are running after them, and companies are working hard at implementing them.\n\nWhile there are not many cases in which the synergy of both is apparent, it holds significant potential for mainstream adoption, especially in decentralized finance. Here is why:\n\nEnhancing DeFi User Adoption\n\nOne of the major hurdles for DeFi adoption is its complexity. AI can play a crucial role in simplifying user interactions with DeFi platforms through AI-driven chatbots and virtual assistants that can guide users through complex DeFi protocols, making them more approachable and user-friendly. Maxim Savelyev, CEO at Web3 consulting firm Empathy Consulting, notes \"Mainstream users can see only the tip of the iceberg of what DeFi can offer, such as the Coinbase Wallet, while the most powerful tools remain locked within the enthusiast community due to their complexity\".\n\nBy analyzing a user's portfolio and behavior, token trends, and whales transactions, AI can offer tailored advice, helping users make informed decisions without needing deep technical knowledge. One example is decentralized hedge fund Numerai that uses AI and machine learning to crowdsource predictions from data scientists, which are then used to trade in the stock market. This approach shows AI's potential to drive investment strategies in a decentralized manner. Additionally, AI-powered platforms like AlphaPoint leverage AI to analyze on-chain data and predict future DeFi asset prices, aiding users in making informed investment decisions.\n\nFraud Prevention And Audit\n\nWith 76 hacks in 2023 resulting in a collective loss of approximately $1.1 billion, according to Chainalysis, security is a paramount concern in DeFi. AI's ability to detect anomalies and suspicious activities in real-time reduces fraud and maintains trust in decentralized platforms. As Lars Nyman of cloud provider CUDO Compute highlights, \"AI can increase security through anomaly detection and improve smart contract functionality via predictive analytics.\" AI can also assist in creating smart contracts, an activity previously reserved for technical practitioners. By verifying smart contracts and identifying potential vulnerabilities, AI ensures higher security standards and boosts trust in blockchain systems.\n\nThat way, decentralized exchange Uniswap employs AI to identify and block fraudulent transactions, ensuring a safer trading environment for its users. Similarly, open source protocol Aave utilizes AI-powered risk management tools to optimize loan health and collateralization requirements, showcasing AI's role in enhancing financial products and services.\n\nMaking Blockchain Data Accessible\n\nBlockchain's transparency is one of its greatest strengths, but the sheer volume of data can make it difficult to derive meaningful insights. AI can bridge this gap by processing and summarizing large datasets, making blockchain data more accessible and smart contract execution more effective. Adnan Masood from solutions provider UST underscores the importance of hybrid approaches where AI processes data off-chain while maintaining on-chain integrity. By transforming raw blockchain data into understandable insights, AI can democratize access to information, allowing users to make better decisions.\n\nAn example of this is Chainalysis, which uses AI to monitor and analyze blockchain transactions for suspicious activities, thereby enhancing security and making the data more accessible for analysis. Another blockchain protocol, Fetch.ai, integrates AI to optimize transaction timing and processing with the goal to reduce congestion.\n\nImproving Tools For Blockchain Developers\n\nAI can also enhance the quality of life for blockchain developers by providing low-code and copilot-like solutions. These tools can simplify the development process, reduce the need for extensive coding knowledge, and accelerate project timelines. One example is multichain protocol Guru Network, which provides a low-code solution that integrates traditional business process automation engines with AI snippets to streamline the creation of Web3 and AI applications. Developers can use pre-built components and templates, while GPT agents provide real-time, context-aware consultation from documentation and code repositories.\n\nAI can assist in generating smart contracts, debugging code, and predicting potential issues before they arise. This not only speeds up development but also reduces the margin for error, allowing developers to focus on more strategic and innovative aspects of their projects. AI can also help with the creation of smart contracts, making the development process more accessible to non-technical practitioners.\n\nFor example, open-source framework OpenZeppelin employs AI to audit smart contracts, identifying bugs and vulnerabilities before deployment. This proactive approach ensures that smart contracts are secure and function as intended, reducing the likelihood of errors and exploits. Similarly, Ocean Protocol uses AI to develop deterministic models that align with blockchain's deterministic nature, enhancing the overall development process.\n\nAI is transforming the DeFi landscape, bridging the gap between complex financial technologies and everyday users. By enhancing infrastructure, improving user experience, providing robust security measures, and supporting developers, it is making DeFi more accessible and efficient.\n\nAs these technologies continue to evolve, we can expect AI to play a more impactful role in the mainstream adoption of DeFi. By leveraging AI's analytical prowess and ability to handle large data sets, DeFi platforms can offer more secure, efficient, and user-friendly financial services, ultimately democratizing finance and empowering users worldwide.", "source": {"uri": "forbes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Forbes"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralized_finance", "type": {"uri": "8233117251", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "08:25:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T08:25:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T08:24:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://yourstory.com/2024/07/top-5-free-ai-image-generators", "title": "Top 5 free AI image generators to elevate your designs", "body": "In the era of AI, digital content gets the best seats. As visual content plays a crucial role in engaging audiences online, AI image generators have become a game-changers for content creators and marketers.\n\nThese AI tools generate high-quality images effortlessly making it a need for businesses to level up their branding. In today's article, we have compiled a list of the top 5 best free AI image generators that you need to try out!\n\nAdobe is a renowned name in the world of design, and its AI image generator, Firefly, lives up to its reputation. This tool uses a \"Text-to-image\" model powered by Image 3 which helps to create stunning visuals in a matter of seconds by machine learning algorithms. Even so, the platform gives you the option to utilise Firefly Image 2 or Image 3 AI model.\n\nThe free version of this tool offers a wide range of customisation options like aspect ratio, effects, colour and tone, lighting and even the camera angle. Moreover, you can add reference images to adjust the style and composition to enhance the result. However, there are only 25 monthly credits available on the free version. Overall, Adobe Firefly is a must-have for anyone looking to create eye-catching images.\n\nMeta AI is a new AI assistant launched by the firm. It can perform various tasks like content generation, brainstorming ideas, planning things, and even creating AI images. You will require a Facebook account on the website browser version to access this tool. Apart from that, Meta AI is also available on WhatsApp and Instagram.\n\nWhen it comes to image generation, users can simply type @Imagine and write the text prompt. The best part of Meta AI is that there is no limit to generating images as long as it adheres to the guidelines. However, the catch is that the images contain watermarks and the AI model cannot handle long or complex text prompts. So if you need to quickly make simple AI-generated designs, Meta AI has got you covered.\n\nBing Image Creator is a versatile AI image generator powered by OpenAI's Dall E 3 AI model and comes with a plethora of features. All you need is a Microsoft account and you can do anything from basic image editing to creating complex designs.\n\nAlso, you can make around 15 images daily in the free version. Surprisingly you can still create designs even after exhausting these credits but the output will be slow. If you have a pro licence of Co-pilot then you can get around 100 boosts every day.\n\nMoreover, designers can further customise these images on Microsoft Designer which comes with an intuitive interface and an extensive library of assets. In short, Bing Image Creator is a top choice for both beginners and experienced designers.\n\nGemini AI is a user-friendly AI image generator that is perfect for those who just want 1:1 aspect ratio pictures. This free tool offers to make various digital arts from fantasy portraits to realistic images given that your text prompt describes what you want correctly. While you can create unlimited images, Google has paused the AI-image generation of humans since that feature needs improvement.\n\nCanva is a popular online design platform that has recently introduced AI capabilities. With Canva Magic Media, you can create professional-looking visuals in minutes, thanks to its easy-to-use interface. Their image generator is powered by Dall-E and its free version has a quota of 50 credits.\n\nGetting your hands on Canva AI can help you understand how AI image generators function so feel free to be creative with your prompts. Once credits are exhausted, users can upgrade to a premium plan that is quite flexible. It even offers subscriptions as low as Rs 69 for 1 day.\n\nSo, whether you are designing a logo, social media post, or presentation slide, Canva has all the tools you need to bring your ideas to life.\n\nAI image generators have revolutionised the way we create visual content. With these top 5 best free AI image generators, you can harness the power of artificial intelligence to elevate your designs and make a lasting impact on your audience. So, give them a try today and unlock a world of creative possibilities. {"uri": "8233873953", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "16:49:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T16:49:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T16:49:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=755913df-345c-4867-87ec-173894cd5c37", "title": "What's on the horizon for AI regulation in the UK?", "body": "King's Speech makes reference to government plans to establish 'appropriate legislation'\n\nOn 17 July 2024, King Charles III read the King's Speech at the State Opening of Parliament, outlining the Labour government's legislative programme for the coming year. The speech encompassed a package of around 40 proposed bills. But much has been left unsaid as to exactly how it plans to regulate artificial intelligence (if indeed at all).\n\nThe previous UK government took a relatively \"hands off\" approach in terms of regulating AI, especially in comparison with the landmark EU Artificial Intelligence Act (EU AI Act).\n\nThe new government looks set to take a different approach - it intends to \"establish the appropriate legislation to place requirements on those working to develop the most powerful artificial intelligence models\".\n\nOsborne Clarke comment\n\nGiven the regulatory trend across the globe, it feels inevitable that the UK will move to regulate AI in some way (as was highlighted during the election campaign by Labour).\n\nIt is worth noting that the government will \"seek to establish\" laws around AI. That suggests a period of consultation which could protract timings for introduction of new legislation (if any), given the inherent complexities around regulating AI (including some thorny intellectual property questions).\n\nWhile there is now a marked change of direction by the new government, it remains to be seen whether the UK can enact a coherent and practical piece of law that recognises the rapid advancements in the technology, responds to growing concerns regarding AI safety, and sensibly applies to a technology used in thousands of systems across completely different applications.\n\nAny legislation would also need to carefully balance legitimate concerns around AI while not stifling innovation or disrupting the UK's current prominence in the AI space.\n\nWhile we await flesh on the bones around the UK position, the EU AI Act is now law with the countdown starting for compliance. While the principles behind the EU's AI Act are laudable, there are many elements of the regulation that pose more questions than they resolve.\n\nThe divergence in approach could add weight to the argument that the EU AI Act will become the \"gold standard\" and become the one which businesses - which rightly are calling for certainty in this space - start to gear their compliance regimes {"uri": "8232567553", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "23:22:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T23:22:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T23:21:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://news.northeastern.edu/2024/07/18/healey-ai-task-force-northeastern/", "title": "'AI will transform every aspect of our life,' Gov. Healey says at artificial intelligence task force meeting at Northeastern", "body": "Massachusetts Gov. Maura Healey, Boston Mayor Michelle Wu, state economic development and technology leaders and other officials visited Northeastern's Boston campus on Thursday to learn from university professors how artificial intelligence can solve some of the most pressing issues in the state and the world.\n\n\"AI is a technology with the potential to transform -- not just the potential, it will transform -- every aspect of our life,\" Healey said during an event at the EXP research complex. \"Massachusetts innovators, as we'll see in today's presentations, are already at the forefront.\"\n\nProvost David Madigan said Northeastern was the \"exactly the right place to talk about AI,\" pointing out that AI research at the university is being used to detect cancers, track infant health, prevent climate change and more.\n\n\"And all with an eye on ethical AI and responsible AI,\" Madigan said. \"That has been a key theme of everything we do here at this university -- how do we harness this extraordinary technology to do good.\"\n\nThe event occurred prior to a meeting at Northeastern of the Artificial Intelligence Strategic Task Force commissioned by Healey, who also attended the session.\n\nThe taskforce was established in February to study AI and generative artificial intelligence technology and its impact on the state, private businesses, higher education institutions and constituents. It is made up of leaders from large companies, startups, academia, investors and nonprofits.\n\nNortheastern's Usama Fayyad is a member of the task force, and described his work as executive director of The Institute for Experiential AI at the university to those in attendance.\n\nRupal Patel, a professor in the Khoury College of Computer Sciences and the Bouve College of Health Sciences, showcased her work using AI to create bespoke synthesized voices for individuals with various health conditions.\n\nAuroop Ganguly, director of AI for climate and sustainability at The Institute for Experiential AI, gave a presentation on how AI can help predict local flooding -- particularly flooding around Boston's Logan Airport -- from extreme precipitation events.\n\nCollege of Engineering Distinguished Professor Jennifer Dy explained her research with hospitals in New York City and Boston using AI to detect skin cancer and to treat patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.\n\n\"The nice thing about being an AI person in Massachusetts, and in Boston in particular, is that we have world-leading hospitals that are highly concentrated in the area,\" Dy said.\n\n\"And with advances in AI, there's a lot that we can do together.\"\n\nTaskin Padir, director of the Institute for Experiential Robotics at Northeastern, finished the presentations by showcasing a robotic arm with a gripper inspired by chopsticks that can help seafood processors sort and grade scallops.\n\n\"We are so fortunate to have you all here in Boston,\" Healey told the professors before she, Wu and Economic Development Secretary Yvonne Hao took turns operating the robot. \"I know they'll appreciate this in New Bedford.\"\n\nHealey said repeatedly during the event that she wants Massachusetts to become a global hub for applied AI -- finding real-world applications for AI -- just as the state is a hub for the life sciences.\n\nShe said a $2.8 billion economic development bond bill she has proposed called the Mass Leads Act is crucial to this goal.\n\nThe bill includes $100 million to leverage AI to spur technological advances in the life sciences, health care, advanced manufacturing and robotics sectors, support incubation of AI startups, advance AI software and hardware tech development, and support commercialization activities. This funding would also incentivize public-private partnerships between industry and academia.\n\n\"It's about taking that knowledge and making it practical,\" Healey said.\n\nAlso crucial to the goal are universities like Northeastern, as Healey referenced the Huskies who recently completed projects for the state through the AI for Impact Co-op Program.\n\n\"What I saw with the students is it can just cut exponentially the amount of time it takes to get answers to people,\" Healey said, referencing one of the students' projects, which included work for The Ride paratransit service and streamlining the grants process with the Office of Energy and Environmental Affair.\n\n\"It will get better service and better answers to customers, whether they're people looking for grant funding, people looking for permitting, you know, or other customers that we serve as a government and it's really exciting,\" she said.\n\n\"Our universities are really our secret sauce, and they have been for so many parts of our economy,\" added Hao.\n\nShe noted that Massachusetts leads the country in terms of AI graduates per capita and is among the top states for AI graduates.\n\n\"We have the talent here at our universities,\" Hao continued. \"Working closely with our cities and our state government and all of our different private sectors, we can really lead here.\"", "source": {"uri":
