Over time, this evolved into man versus or with man. Now, we stand on the brink of a new era: man versus or with AI. \"The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into various facets of our lives has undoubtedly revolutionized industries, economies, and daily activities. However, as we embrace these advancements, it is crucial to explore the potential challenges and ethical dilemmas they present,\" says IAS Subodh Agarwal. {"uri": "2024-07-427389365", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "16:34:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T16:34:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T15:48:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "url": "https://www.fxleaders.com/news/2024/07/19/texas-bitcoin-miners-move-to-artificial-intelligence/", "title": "Texas Bitcoin Miners Move to Artificial Intelligence", "body": "Tech companies in Texas no longer see Bitcoin mining as a viable long-term business. They are turning to the AI market instead as they change up business ventures.\n\nBitcoin was off to a good start in 2024, setting a new record high in the early months. But then cryptocurrency as the market ran up against the wall of high US inflation and started to withdraw. Consumer interest began to wane, and internet searches for Bitcoin greatly increased after March of 2024.\n\nWhat many investors noticed is that AI was taking the place of Bitcoin and crypto as the hot, new tech market. Microsoft, Nvidia, Google, and other tech giants were making billions of dollars in the AI industry, with their stocks rising as they invested more in this emerging market.\n\nIt was not long before the rest of the world started to catch on. Bitcoin was on the wane while AI was on the rise. Over in Texas, there is a shift in the tech culture. The Bitcoin mining farms are coming down and being replaced with data centers to meet the needs of companies focused on AI.\n\nThe AI Takeover\n\nThe doomsday prognosticators warned that artificial intelligence would take over the world, and in Texas, that is at least partially true. AI data centers are being built on the wide open spaces of Houston and Abilene. Cloud computing servers are big business over there, as they are key to providing enough power for AI programs.\n\nSome of the new data centers being built in Texas will be some of the largest in the world when they are completed, and the race is on for companies to be the go-to providers for tech companies that need computing service for their artificial intelligence.\n\nData centers are shifting away from bitcoin mining to cloud computing and the ability to handle massive AI workloads. The energy demands are high, and these data centers need to be able to cool off quickly. All of that capability is being built right into the data centers, which are being designed from the ground up to accommodate AI.\n\nThe shift is already happening, and with fewer bitcoin farms left every month, there may be a fraction of the focus on mining next year as there has been this year. China and Russia are among the major countries that have cracked down on Bitcoin mining and made it harder for miners to create new bitcoin on their soil.\n\nThe shift to AI is happening on multiple fronts. It is taking place because there are greater restrictions for miners than there were in the past, and it is taking place because of the changing focus in the tech market. We expect this shift to continue in the coming months as Bitcoin struggles to get back to its previous highs.", "source": {"uri": "fxleaders.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FX Leaders"}, After the emergence of in-house AI solutions, it looks like the big tech firms are collaborating with Chinese customers to provide them with access to NVIDIA's high-end AI hardware, such as the H100-based AI servers, which can't be directly exported to China. The report comes from The Information, citing unnamed sources within the firms involved in business with China.\n\nExpanding upon the development, the media outlet says that \"renting AI hardware\" to hostile nations is certainly not a violation of US regulations and that firms like Google and Microsoft are indeed involved in this business. Microsoft is responsible for lending NVIDIA's A100 and H100-based servers to Chinese customers, while Google does the same. It looks like despite China not having the supply of NVIDIA's high-end AI servers; the country still has access to modern hardware, which is why the rapid pace of development of the regional AI industry is still there. It should be pointed out that exports of both the A100 and H100 AI accelerators are banned in China.\n\nMoreover, there are sectors of the AI markets that only deal with providing access to NVIDIA's high-end AI servers to customers around the world, with China being a primary dealer. This means that despite the export restriction of NVIDIA's AI hardware, Chinese tech giants like Tencent and Alibaba still have access to the computing power, although they will have to pay the \"rental premium.\"\n\nThe Biden administration has yet to rule on whether this is allowed, but Google is confident that such a business complies with US terms and conditions. China does always find ways to bypass US sanctions, whether it is in the AI hype or something similar. We previously reported on how NVIDIA's H100s were being sold in China's black markets at astonishing prices, which shows that China isn't entirely restricted to NVIDIA's AI hardware.", "source": Digital Health Summit, themed on 'Leveraging AI for Improving Health Outcomes'.\n\nAlso Read | RBI Governor Shaktikanta Das Says Banks and Financial Institutions Need To Maintain Highest Level of Vigil Against Cyberattacks, Digital Frauds.\n\nThe age of artificial intelligence (AI) in digital health has arrived, presenting immense potential across various use cases, Paul said.\n\nHe also highlighted the potential for AI to revolutionise medical education and professional development pathways, suggesting that AI could enhance decision-making processes for physicians, from diagnostic testing to treatment plans.\n\nAlso Read | NEET-UG Paper Leak Case: CBI Arrests Female MBBS Student From RIMS Ranchi Who 'Solved' Papers.\n\nThis event brought together key stakeholders from the healthcare industry, government and technology sectors to explore the transformative potential of AI in healthcare.\n\nCrucial topics such as improvements in care delivery, ethical implementation and responsible AI, sustainable business models and AI-powered data analytics were also discussed.\n\nPaul discussed the government's interest in partnering with the industry to leverage AI for public health dimensions such as individualised care, prediction, targeting and precision public health.\n\nHe mentioned the operationalisation of the Global Initiative on Digital Health (GIDH), an initiative stemming from India's G20 presidency that aims at helping countries utilise digital technologies and ecosystems for development.\n\nThe NITI Aayog member also underscored the significance of the Ayushman Bharat Digital Mission (ABDM), noting that approximately 66 crore ABHA accounts have been opened.\n\nHe urged industry stakeholders to contribute to the mission's refinement and leverage the India AI Mission for collaborative advancements in AI-driven healthcare.\n\nSecretary, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Apurva Chandra, acknowledged the significant strides AI has made, recognizing its potential to transform healthcare.\n\nHe noted that while AI is not yet extensively used within the ministry, there are current applications being utilised in decision support systems, data mining, diagnostics, drug discovery and fraud analytics.\n\nHe described how AI is used in decision support systems like HMIS software, integrated with e-Sanjivani and numerous hospitals and primary care centres to recommend medicines based on past behaviours and learnings.\n\nChandra stressed the need for industry collaboration to further integrate AI into healthcare, particularly in utilising the vast datasets available for public health outcomes, including predicting pandemics and managing non-communicable diseases, communicable diseases, and maternal and child health outcomes.\n\nDuring the event, the 'CII Self-Regulatory Code of Conduct for Telemedicine' and a comprehensive report titled 'Mapping India's Corporate Health and Wellness Landscape' were launched.", {"uri": "8232682242", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "01:52:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T01:52:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T01:51:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/technology/times-techies/why-critical-thinking-is-key-for-engineers-in-this-age-of-ai/articleshow/111849354.cms", "title": "Why critical thinking is key for engineers in this age of AI - Times of India", "body": "As AI reshapes the landscape of technology and industry, engineers find themselves at a crossroads. The question is no longer whether AI will impact their field, but how to adapt and thrive in this new era. In a webinar last week, industry leaders said that there are several critical skills engineers need to develop to stay ahead in this emerging AI-driven world.\n\nAditya Kulkarni, VP of engineering at Dun & Bradstreet, says the predictive and generative capabilities of the latest AI models are transforming various engineering disciplines, creating both opportunities and challenges for engineers. To navigate this new terrain, Aditya says, continuous learning and curiosity are indispensable. Subject matter expertise, he says, will still be more important or as important to what AI can do. Aditya advocates a multi-faceted approach to skill development, including formal education, online resources, mentorship, and hands-on experience.\n\nMasa Karahashi, SVP of engineering at Avalara, says practical engagement with AI tools is enormously beneficial as well. \"If nothing else, just go to OpenAI, create a free account, start using ChatGPT and just talk to it,\" he suggests. This hands-on approach, he says, will allow engineers to develop an intuitive understanding of AI's capabilities and limitations. However, Masa and Aditya emphasise that the ability to critically evaluate AI outputs is perhaps the most crucial skill for engineers to develop. \"It's critical thinking that is most important,\" Masa says. \"Use the tool for what it is, but it's going to give you a certain output, and you've got to look at the output, use your subject matter expertise, and say, 'What is this telling me? What can I do with this data?'\"\n\nThis emphasis on critical thinking is particularly important given the phenomenon of AI hallucinations - instances where AI generates false or misleading information with convincing authority. \"Because it's so easy to use, and a lot of people can use it, I think it's created a new category of problems because people don't understand the shortcomings, specifically around the concept of hallucinations,\" warns Masa. Another key skill set revolves around ethical considerations and compliance, says Aditya. Even on Google search, he says, you can find unsettling answers and images to very simple questions.\n\nNavigating this terrain, he says, involves not just having a thorough understanding of the laws and regulations surrounding AI, but also its wider implications. \"You have to ask if AI is getting used responsibly; does it have a bias. And once it is ethically and legally compliant, is it something that is ready for the world?\" Integration skills are also becoming important. Aditya notes that once engineers understand the problems and the limitations of AI systems, then comes the complex task of integrating the AI solution at scale. This, he says, requires a strategic approach that considers factors such as the cost-effectiveness of any AI solution, the legal hurdles it may face, and project-specific needs.\n\nMasa also adds a word of caution. \"Recognise that if you just take the output of GenAI and then just use it as your work...the audience that you're working with, they're familiar with GenAI too. And they can spot an output of GenAI from a mile away.\" Which is why Masa says it behoves engineers to get into the habit of customising and refining AI outputs, rather than simply accepting them at face value.", "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Times of India"}, "authors": [{"uri": "shilpa_phadnis@timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "name": "Shilpa {"uri": "8233941261", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:45:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:45:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:43:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://www.omanobserver.om/article/1156523/business/markets/ais-insatiable-energy-use-drives-electricity-demands", "title": "AI's insatiable energy use drives electricity demands", "body": "GPUs, used to train large language models and respond to ChatGPT queries, requires more energy than your average microchip and give off more heat\n\nA few weeks ago, I joined a small group of reporters for a wide-ranging conversation with Bill Gates about climate change, its causes and potential solutions. When the topic turned to the issue of just how much energy artificial intelligence was using, Gates was surprisingly sanguine.\n\n\"Let's not go overboard on this,\" he said during a media briefing on the sidelines of an event he was hosting in London.\n\nAI data centers represent a relatively small additional load on the grid, Gates said. What's more, he predicted that insights gleaned from AI would deliver gains in efficiency that would more than make up for that additional demand.\n\nIn short, Gates said, the stunning rise of AI will not stand in the way of combating climate change. \"It's not like, 'Oh, no, we can't do it because we're addicted to doing chat sessions,'\" he said.\n\nThat's an upbeat assessment from a billionaire with a vested interest in the matter. Gates is a big-time climate investor, and is the former head of Microsoft and remains a major stockholder in the company, which is at the center of the AI revolution.\n\nAnd while it's too early to draw a definitive conclusion on the issue, a few things are already clear: AI is having a profound impact on energy demand around the world, it's often leading to an uptick in planet-warming emissions, and there's no end in sight.\n\nAI data centers have a big appetite for electricity. The so-called graphic processing units, or GPUs, used to train large language models and respond to ChatGPT queries, require more energy than your average microchip and give off more heat.\n\nWith more data centers coming online almost every week, projections about how much energy will be required to power the AI boom are soaring.\n\nOne peer-reviewed study suggested AI could make up 0.5 per cent of worldwide electricity use by 2027, or roughly what Argentina uses in a year. Analysts at Wells Fargo suggested that US electricity demand could jump 20 per cent by 2030, driven in part to AI.\n\nAnd Goldman Sachs predicted that data centers would account for 8 per cent of US energy usage in 2030, up from just 3 per cent today.\n\n\"It's truly astronomical potential load growth,\" said Ben Inskeep, the program director at Citizens Action Coalition, a consumer watchdog group based in Indiana that is tracking the energy impact of data centers.\n\nMicrosoft, Google, Amazon and Meta have all recently announced plans to build new data centers in Indiana, developments that Inskeep said would strain the grid.\n\n\"We don't have enough power to meet the projected needs of data centers over the next five to 10 years,\" he said. \"We would need a massive build-out of additional resources.\" Tech giants are scrambling to get a grip on their energy usage. For a decade now, those same four companies have been at the forefront of corporate efforts to embrace sustainability.\n\nBut in a matter of months, the energy demands from AI have complicated that narrative. Google's emissions last year were 50 per cent higher than in 2019, largely because of data centers and the rise of AI. Microsoft's emissions also jumped for the same reasons, up 29 per cent last year from 2020. And Meta's emissions jumped 66 per cent from 2021 to 2023.\n\nIn statements, Google and Microsoft both said that AI would ultimately prove crucial to addressing the climate crisis, and that they were working to reduce their carbon footprints and bring more clean energy online. Amazon pointed to a statement detailing its sustainability efforts.\n\nThere are two ways for tech companies to meet the demand: tap the existing grid, or build new power plants. Each poses its own challenges.\n\nIn West Virginia, coal-fired power plants that had been scheduled to retire are being kept online to meet the energy needs of new data centers across the border in Virginia.\n\nAnd across the country, utilities are building new natural-gas infrastructure to support data centers. Goldman Sachs anticipates that \"incremental data center power consumption in the US will drive around 3.3 billion cubic feet per day of new natural gas demand by 2030, which will require new pipeline capacity to be built.\"\n\nAt the same time, the tech giants are working to secure a lot more power to fuel the growth of AI.\n\nMicrosoft is working on a $10 billion plan to develop renewable energy to power data centers. Amazon has said it used 100 per cent clean energy last year, though experts have questioned whether the company's accounting was too lenient.\n\nAll that new low carbon power is great. But when the tech companies themselves are consuming all that electricity to power new AI data centers, pushing up energy demand, it isn't making the grid overall any cleaner.\n\nThe energy demands from AI are only getting more intense. Microsoft and OpenAI are planning on building a $100 billion data center, according to reports. Initial reporting suggests it may require 5 gigawatts of power, or roughly the equivalent of five nuclear reactors.\n\nAnd at the same time that companies are building more data centers, many of the chips at the heart of the AI revolution are getting more and more power hungry. Nvidia, the leader in AI chips, recently unveiled new products that would draw exponentially more energy from the grid.\n\nThe AI boom is generating big profits for some companies. And it may yet deliver breakthroughs that help reduce emissions. But, at least for now, data centers are doing more harm than good for the climate.\n\n\"It's definitely very concerning as we're trying to transition our current grid to renewable energy,\" Inskeep said. \"Adding a massive amount of new load on top of that poses a grave threat to that transition.\" -- The New York Times\n\nGRAPH POINTS\n\n1. AI could make up 0.5 per cent of worldwide electricity use by 2027, or roughly what Argentina uses in a year.\n\n2. GPUs require more energy than your average microchip and give off more heat\n\n3. Microsoft and OpenAI are planning on building a $100 billion data center. It may require 5 gigawatts of power, or roughly the equivalent of five nuclear reactors.\n\n4. Data centers would account for 8 per cent of US energy usage in 2030, up from just 3 per cent today.", "source": {"uri": "omanobserver.om", "dataType": "news", "title": "Oman Observer"}, "authors": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9737001", "eventUri": "eng-9737001", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2862745098039217, "wgt": 109, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-426439742", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "20:52:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T20:52:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T20:50:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/tech/2793722/", "title": "The power of AI and intelligent voice", "body": "At the time, Voice Computer Technologies was attracting a lot of attention for its cutting-edge voice response system. Despite the word \"voice\" in the name, the system used a prerecorded voice that asked callers to press 1 for \"yes\" and 2 for \"no,\" or to enter a series of digits from a printed catalog. In 1984, the voice response system was expected to help college students register for classes.\n\nThirty years after the system's debut, the film Her was released. The movie tells the story of a lovelorn man who falls in love with an intelligent computer operating system. This human-like voice becomes an invaluable companion, living within the operating system and able to read and evaluate all of your emails, text messages, and stored files. With your permission (and sometimes without), it responds to your emails, makes recommendations, buys products, and is available 24/7. Given the rapid advances in artificial intelligence, the storyline in this movie may be more compelling today than it was when the movie was first released.\n\nSo what do these two technologies, 30 years apart, have in common? Voice communications and AI have converged to create a new category of artificial intelligence called Conversational AI, a rapidly evolving field that is continually improving its ability to understand and interact with humans naturally and effectively.\n\nKeeping up with AI applications and new startups is already a challenge, with new services and applications emerging almost every week. But Hume.AI is notable for its foray into the new field of conversational AI. The tech company measures hundreds of emotional dimensions through real-time conversations between users and its proprietary chatbot. Hume.AI claims that its empathetic voice interface is the world's first emotionally intelligent voice, trained on millions of human interactions.\n\nWith humans no longer tethered to keyboards, advances in AI and quick two-way conversations that can be instantly translated into dozens of different languages have made chatbots more meaningful.\n\nIt's no surprise that local governments, the ones closest to their citizens, are leveraging AI and voice in a variety of important ways. They're already using generative AI to help civil servants work more efficiently, improve how they communicate with citizens, and better design services.\n\nBelow are just some of the ways governments are considering deploying conversational AI.\n\nAccessibility and convenience: Voice-activated AI assistants like Siri, Alexa, and Google Assistant make technology accessible to a wider range of users, including people with disabilities. Users can perform tasks hands-free, improving convenience and productivity. AI-powered chatbots and voice assistants can provide service around the clock by answering common questions and guiding citizens through various services without human intervention.\n\nCustomer service: AI-powered chatbots and voice assistants improve customer service by providing fast and accurate answers to common inquiries, reducing wait times and allowing human agents to handle more complex issues.\n\nPersonalization: AI can analyze vast amounts of data to provide personalized recommendations and experiences, and voice technology can enhance this by recognizing an individual's voice and preferences.\n\nAutomation: Voice commands enable smart home automation, allowing users to control lights, thermostats, security systems and more with simple voice commands.\n\nHealthcare: AI and voice technology are being used in healthcare as virtual assistants to help manage patient records, schedule appointments, and provide basic medical advice, improving efficiency and patient care. In Washington, DC, officials recently employed generative AI to create the Knowledge Assist chatbot, which allows residents and employees to ask questions about various health programs, such as vaccines and nutrition services, and get quick, accurate answers.\n\nEducation: Voice assistants and virtual tutors can help in education by helping students study, providing information, and even facilitating language learning through conversation practice. Khan Academy is already leveraging this through the introduction of Khanmigo, which benefits both learners and teachers.\n\nWorkplace efficiency: In professional environments, AI and voice technology can improve productivity by streamlining workflows, helping with schedule management, providing reminders, and facilitating quick access to information.\n\nNatural Interaction: Speech technology enables more natural human-computer interaction, making it easy to communicate with devices in the same way you communicate with other people.\n\nMultilingual Translation: AI-powered speech translation services break down language barriers and enable real-time communication between people who speak different languages.\n\nThe future of AI-powered voice applications is very exciting, and the emergence of emotionally intelligent interfaces is starting to enable some very interesting applications.\n\nFor example, measuring emotions and feelings can enhance social services, mental health counseling, 311 call centers, and perhaps even 911 systems in emergency situations. AI voice systems can measure anger, frustration, hostility, stress, and emotional distress. Such systems should be trained to accurately determine when to direct callers to highly trained personnel who can best respond when automated responses fall short. These same systems can translate such emotions into useful structured data for public managers to review, respond, and plan future interventions. AI can play a key role in analyzing large datasets to provide insights to policymakers, which can then make more informed decisions about various aspects of local governance, from urban planning to resource allocation.\n\nLocal governments face many challenges in adoption. Government employees need to be trained to use these new technologies effectively and integrate them into their workflows. Decisions must be made about when to transfer chatbot responsibilities to humans, and under what conditions and circumstances. Second, technology infrastructure challenges are anticipated. Local governments will need to invest in the technology infrastructure required to support AI and voice technology. As voice systems become more natural and human-like, local governments will need to provide disclaimers and statements in their AI usage policies.\n\nBut like any technology, there is a dark side that is often overlooked. For convincing and lifelike AI-powered voice interfaces, we need to worry about over-reliance on machines. We need to worry about how, for how long, under what conditions conversational data and information is stored and who can access it. We can't assume that conversion AI can keep secrets.\n\nMachines that appear to think, feel, and communicate, however fascinating, present interesting ethical and moral challenges. The machines essentially spend all their time studying and learning about humans, and this alone is worrisome, to say the least. Those old enough to remember the movie 2001: A Space Odyssey, released almost 50 years ago, are troubled by the meaning of the famous line, \"Hal, open the bay door.\" In this brief scene, Hal is the master control computer system, speaking, thinking, and ultimately concluding that the human crew are a threat to the mission. Hal actively tries to kill the crew. At this moment, in real time, we are blissfully in control of the computer system. But when we converse with a machine that thinks and speaks alongside us, we can't help but wonder where this is leading us.\n\nDr. Alan R. Shirk is Executive Director of the Public Technology Institute (PTI) and Associate Professor in the Schar School of Policy and Government at George Mason University, where he is also affiliated faculty with the Center for Advancing Human-Machine Partnerships (CAHMP). Dr. Shirk is a Fellow of the National Academy of Public Administration and Co-Chair of its Standing Committee on Technology Leadership. Dr. Shirk also hosts the bi-monthly podcast Sharkbytes.net. Dr. Shirk acknowledges collaboration with Generative AI in the development of certain materials.\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online\n\nLOS ANGELES, CA / ACCESSWIRE / June 24, 2020, / Compare-autoinsurance.Org has launched a new blog post that presents the main benefits of comparing multiple car insurance quotes. For more info and free online quotes, please visit https://compare-autoinsurance.Org/the-advantages-of-comparing-prices-with-car-insurance-quotes-online/ The modern society has numerous technological advantages. One important advantage is the speed at which information is sent and received. With the help of the internet, the shopping habits of many persons have drastically changed. The car insurance industry hasn't remained untouched by these changes. On the internet, drivers can compare insurance prices and find out which sellers have the best offers. View photos The advantages of comparing online car insurance quotes are the following: Online quotes can be obtained from anywhere and at any time. Unlike physical insurance agencies, websites don't have a specific schedule and they are available at any time. Drivers that have busy working schedules, can compare quotes from anywhere and at any time, even at midnight. Multiple choices. Almost all insurance providers, no matter if they are well-known brands or just local insurers, have an online presence. Online quotes will allow policyholders the chance to discover multiple insurance companies and check their prices. Drivers are no longer required to get quotes from just a few known insurance companies. Also, local and regional insurers can provide lower insurance rates for the same services. Accurate insurance estimates. Online quotes can only be accurate if the customers provide accurate and real info about their car models and driving history. Lying about past driving incidents can make the price estimates to be lower, but when dealing with an insurance company lying to them is useless. Usually, insurance companies will do research about a potential customer before granting him coverage. Online quotes can be sorted easily. Although drivers are recommended to not choose a policy just based on its price, drivers can easily sort quotes by insurance price. Using brokerage websites will allow drivers to get quotes from multiple insurers, thus making the comparison faster and easier. {"uri": "8232891597", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "05:33:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T05:33:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T05:33:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "url": "https://analyticsindiamag.com/industry-insights/generative-ai-is-eerily-bringing-deceased-family-members-back-to-life/", "title": "Generative AI is Eerily Bringing Deceased Family Members Back to Life", "body": "DeepBrain AI's Jungwook (John) Son said limits on current technology meant that developing AI chatbots modelled on deceased people was not only uncomfortable but also required a lot of time and resources to get done right.\n\nCalifornia-based generative AI startup DeepBrain AI released re;memory 2, a service to help grieving families recreate their deceased loved ones using generative AI, in June this year.\n\nThis was just the latest development in a fairly new area of generative AI, now being referred to as \"grief tech\". Earlier this year, the use of AI to recreate deceased family members gained prominence, with several Chinese companies making waves, including SenseTime who delivered an AI-generated video of their founder Tang Xiao'ou, who had died late last year, to their employees.\n\nShortly after this, families that had come out in favour of using AI modelled on their deceased family members were attacked for making use of the tech. While some said that it was an unethical use of AI, others said that it served to worsen the mourning period.\n\nHowever, while many have made their minds up on generative AI used for grieving, the methods by which this is done has changed significantly, as companies realise the challenges in making chatbots modelled on deceased loved ones to converse with grieving families.\n\nThe timeline of re;memory's development reflects this realisation, as it's initial iteration was in the form of a conversational chatbot.\n\nSpeaking with AIM, DeepBrain AI global marketing manager Jungwook (John) Son said that current technology meant that developing AI chatbots modelled on deceased people was not only uncomfortable but also required a lot of time and resources to get done right.\n\n\"Our first version of Rememory was conversational and it was very limited. The actual target model had to be in our studio to be generated as an AI avatar, which meant pre-preparing ahead of time. Which is, I would say, a very uncomfortable moment,\" said Son.\n\nAdditionally, due to the sensitive nature of the product, having to get the actual likeness and manner of speaking down while having a back and forth was a monumental task.\n\nIn re;memory's case, the company had this realisation back in 2023, about a year after its first launch. \"We decided to discontinue because we learned the difficulty of actually producing the product. We got some good feedback that's why we decided to pivot and create a video product rather than a conversational product. So, we relaunched it,\" he said.\n\nWhich seems to be something that other companies that have gone into the field of grief tech have realised as well. Many of the companies offering the services, usually offer a video-based product, rather than a conversational one.\n\nEarlier this year, popular Taiwanese musician Bao Xiaobo had gone viral for generating a video of his deceased daughter using AI. During an interview on the subject, he said, \"AI is a tool for expressing yearning, a way to express missing someone.\"\n\nSimilarly, while there are beliefs that AI is being used to recreate or even replace deceased loved ones...\n\nFamilies choosing to use these services seem to be doing so with an understanding that it's more of a tool rather than a replacement for grief.\n\nDeepbrain's model is developed in-house by the team, as their primary product is AI avatars, having provided their services to large-scale retailers, finance and banking companies, and even sports teams across the world.\n\nIn terms of the funeral industry, DeepBrain AI has partnered with one of South Korea's largest funeral service providers, Preedlife, to offer its re;memory services to grieving families.\n\nThe current iteration of re;memory generates a video of the family's deceased loved one, with inputs from the family at every step of the way, from the message they want delivered to the end product. This will be displayed during the funeral of said member, and will also be available to the family, much like looking through a photo album.\n\n\"It would be something that we discuss with the family. There will be an episode that they want to talk about and then we'll moderate it and generate the message using memorable scenes. We try to focus on capture unique facial expressions and voice intonations so that we can try to make it real as possible,\" Son said.\n\nDeepBrain AI's shift from conversational chatbots to video-based memorials reflects a broader industry trend, driven by the realisation that creating lifelike digital avatars of deceased loved ones is riddles with difficulties and sensitivities, as well as other factors like limited reach as well.\n\n\"Because of the limited access, we are currently trying to reach out to more people. So this is why we currently decided to pivot because of the difficulty to create it as a product, whereas now since its a video, it's more reachable, it's more continuable,\" Son said.\n\nDeepbrain AI's collaboration with Preedlife is the first such partnership to happen. However, with a growing acceptance of grief tech, this partnership could be replicated across the board, as families find a certain comfort in these snapshots of their deceased loved ones.\n\nAs Son said, \"We sincerely think the technology will evolve. The feedback that we get is that this does help families emotionally grieve. Grieving is something that people take very seriously.\n\nBut with this type of supplement, I would say, it helps process things more smoother and healthier, and that's the basic approach that we're trying to have here as well.\"", "source": {"uri": "analyticsindiamag.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Analytics India Magazine"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-427322041", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "15:22:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T15:22:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T15:12:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "url": "https://jeroen-erne.medium.com/unlocking-productivity-how-cybersecurity-analysts-can-leverage-ai-tools-6d13afc9667b", "title": "Unlocking Productivity: How Cybersecurity Analysts Can Leverage AI Tools", "body": "Artificial Intelligence (AI) has revolutionized various industries, and cybersecurity is no exception. For Cybersecurity Analysts, the ability to streamline repetitive tasks, improve decision-making, and enhance analytics represents a significant productivity boon. Gone are the days when analysts had to wade through endless logs and alerts manually. By leveraging AI, they can focus on more strategic initiatives and complex tasks that require human intuition and judgment.\n\nAI tools like ChatGPT can analyze vast amounts of data quickly, detect anomalies, generate insights, and even simulate complex attack scenarios. Using AI helps in achieving faster and more accurate threat detection, thereby minimizing potential damage. The productivity gains are immense: analysts can do more, do it faster, and do it with greater precision.\n\nKey Tasks Cybersecurity Analysts Can Accomplish with ChatGPT\n\nThreat Intelligence and Analysis\n\nChatGPT can rapidly sift through large datasets from various intelligence feeds and generate accurate threat models. Analyzing threat intelligence manually is time-consuming and often error-prone. ChatGPT can provide summarized insights, identify patterns, and even suggest mitigation strategies.\n\nSecurity Incident Response\n\nWhen a security incident occurs, time is of the essence. ChatGPT can assist in coordinating the response by quickly analyzing logs, suggesting immediate actions based on predefined playbooks, and providing situational awareness. The tool's ability to contextualize information can significantly reduce the mean time to respond (MTTR).\n\nCompliance and Reporting\n\nGenerating compliance reports is a tedious but necessary part of a Cybersecurity Analyst's job. ChatGPT can automate the generation of these reports, pulling from various data sources and ensuring information is accurate and up-to-date.\n\nEffective Prompts for Cybersecurity Analysts Using ChatGPT\n\nPrompts for Threat Intelligence\n\n\"Analyze the threat landscape and identify potential risks for our company's network.\"\n\n\"Summarize the latest ransomware threats and their impact on similar industries.\"\n\nPrompts for Incident Response\n\n\"Provide step-by-step instructions to mitigate a DDoS attack based on our security playbooks.\"\n\n\"Analyze the following server logs and highlight any suspicious activities.\"\n\nPrompts for Compliance\n\n\"Generate a compliance report for GDPR based on the following datasets.\"\n\n\"Summarize our last quarter's security audits and identify areas for improvement.\"\n\nOther AI Tools Empowering Cybersecurity Analysts\n\nDarktrace\n\nDarktrace leverages machine learning to detect and respond to threats autonomously in real-time. By modeling patterns of life, Darktrace can identify deviations, detect emerging threats, and even initiate automatic responses to neutralize threats at machine speed.\n\nSplunk\n\nSplunk utilizes AI-driven insights to help analysts monitor, search, and analyze machine data. Its predictive analytics features allow for proactive threat detection and faster incident response.\n\nIBM QRadar\n\nIBM QRadar uses AI to correlate data and detect complex attacks across enterprise systems. The platform's machine learning algorithms enhance the accuracy of threat identification, reducing false positives and ensuring a better prioritization of alerts.\n\nThe Future of AI in Cybersecurity\n\nAI's role in cybersecurity is poised to grow significantly. Future advancements may include automated threat hunting, where AI can autonomously explore networks to find vulnerabilities, and predictive analytics that anticipate potential threats before they even manifest. Natural language processing, like that employed by ChatGPT, will likely become even more powerful, enabling it to understand and interpret nuanced cybersecurity languages and signals more accurately.\n\nMoreover, AI will deepen its integration with IoT security, protecting the increasing number of connected devices. AI-driven deception technologies that create decoy environments to lure and analyze attackers are also expected to become mainstream.\n\nThe Imperative to Learn AI: Secure Your Future\n\nIn an evolving threat landscape, staying ahead of attackers requires leveraging all available tools, and AI is at the forefront of this arsenal. The notion that AI will replace Cybersecurity Analysts is a myth; however, analysts who master AI will undoubtedly outpace those who do not. As organizations increasingly adopt AI for their cybersecurity operations, the demand for professionals who understand and can effectively use these tools will soar.\n\nLearning AI not only enhances your productivity but also boosts your career prospects. Analysts proficient in AI can identify threats quicker, execute responses more efficiently, and tackle more complex security challenges, translating to more significant career advancements and higher earnings.", "source": {"uri": "jeroen-erne.medium.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medium"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jeroen@jeroen-erne.medium.com", "name": "Jeroen", "type": "author", "isAgency": {"uri": "8233452545", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:59:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:59:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:58:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "url": "https://blogs.imperial.ac.uk/imperial-people/2024/07/19/artificial-intelligence-futurists/", "title": "Artificial Intelligence Futurists - Imperial people", "body": "\"Our curiosity in exploring AI is shaped by our individual experiences of Imperial as a community that is open to innovation and positive change.\"\n\nAs Imperial's newly appointed Artificial Intelligence (AI) Futurists, we hope to be at the forefront of how our community shapes its response to new technologies, particularly within the education field.\n\nIndividually, we are a diverse group and bring our own experiences to these new planning, engagement, and 'blue-sky-thinking' positions which will sit within different parts of the university. We are all longstanding members of the community with day jobs across the three Faculties and the Business School, and we have been in our new roles for several weeks now.\n\nWe consider AI to be emblematic of a deeper level of change within our professional and personal lives. When several of us first began our careers, the internet was a tool embedded across daily life in a way that few thought could be substantially 'bettered'. Then came along social media and smart devices which provide us with significant access to information but can whittle away our time management skills and attention spans. Fast forward a decade, and we now find how we run our offices, our teaching activity, and our homes to be changed beyond recognition in positive and challenging ways. As AI Futurists, we want to support colleagues and students navigate another wave of change, and perhaps apply their approach toward other changes in education, employment, and wider society. Our curiosity in exploring AI very much feels shaped by our individual experiences of Imperial as a community that is open to innovation and positive change.\n\nSo, let us introduce ourselves...\n\nCaroline Clewley is currently the lead of the I-Explore programme and project lead of ImpVis - a staff-student project creating interactive visualisations for STEM courses. She has long aimed to enable students to experience meaningful extra-curricular activities, and this is reflected in her role as the Futurist who will be working across the entire university.\n\nJay DesLauriers is the AI Futurist of the Business School, currently working as a Teaching Fellow in the Graduate School, within the Research Computing and Data Science group. He also teaches for the Business School via the 'Applications of R for Finance' module.\n\nRhodri Nelson has been appointed in the Faculty of Engineering and hopes to engage with colleagues in the coming months on what matters most to them as AI becomes more embedded across departments. His research interests include the application of complex and numerical analysis to fluid dynamics, geophysics and other engineering related problems. He's also a senior developer of the Devito Project.\n\nEmma Blyth covers the Faculty of Medicine, a fast-growing area for AI development both in terms of teaching and in its applications in the health service in the UK and overseas. As a senior learning designer, she currently closely with academic colleagues to develop high quality learning experiences. In her Futurist role she will be chairing a Faculty-wide AI discussion group.\n\nKonstantinos Beis represents the Faculty of Natural Sciences - a highly lab-based section of the university, and an area in which AI promises to make great strides in our understanding within the field of life sciences. His lab group is interested in determining the structure and function of proteins to support society to understand drug resistance more fully.\n\nCoco Nijhoff leads the AI Futurists' overarching objectives, facilitating discussions and communicating the work of the group to the wider College AI Working Party. She is normally responsible for the strategic development and management of Library Services' Information and Digital Literacy programmes, in alignment with the university's Learning and Teaching Strategy. Coco has produced an Information and Digital Literacy framework to incorporate generative AI, which will form the basis of the library's teaching activities across Imperial.\n\nWe hope to meet colleagues across the university in the coming weeks and months. If you see us around campuses, do say hello. We will be more visible across Imperial from the beginning of the next academic year. In the meantime, we are keen to remind education staff and students that online resources and primers are readily available to browse over the summer.\n\nBy Gordon Short\n\nCategorised under The delivery of previously unimaginable capabilities and the promise of future productivity/efficiency are fueling rapidly broadening AI investments.\n\nSpending on AI have now been elevated to \"mission-critical\" status for companies across all sectors.\n\nThis rapid expansion in AI investments have unveiled the constraints of two key inputs for AI development - chips and power. The bottlenecks within the leading-edge semiconductors supply chain are now well understood and have greatly benefited the effective monopolies in the space such as Nvidia, Taiwan Semi Conductor and {"uri": "8227575901", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-16", "time": "05:36:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-16T05:36:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-16T05:36:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4000000059604645, "url": "https://www.personneltoday.com/hr/ai-productivity-workday/", "title": "Using AI to full potential could unlock \u00a3119bn in productivity", "body": "Business leaders could unlock more than four hours a day if AI tools were used to their full potential, according to a report by Workday.\n\nThe HR software company asked employees and leaders how much time could be saved each day if AI was used to its maximum potential. Employees believed they would save 2.9 hours each day and business leaders almost doubled this estimate at 4.4 hours.\n\nThe report, The UK Productivity Gap: How AI can unlock workplace potential, calculated that employees would save 737 hours per year (92 days) based on how much time they thought they would save, and leaders 1,117 (140 days a year).\n\nIf employees could be productive for an additional 2.9 hours of work per day, this would unlock the equivalent of \u00a311,058 a year of added work based on reported salaries, it estimated.\n\nThis would mean that, across 10 million employees in large businesses across the UK, \u00a3119 billion worth of productive work each year could be unlocked.\n\nHowever, concerns around trust and privacy remain a barrier to companies' adoption of AI tools, and this was the case for 93% of both employees and leaders.\n\nAmong leaders, 38% had fears over safety, privacy or bias, while 34% felt they needed more time to educate their teams. Almost a third (32%) blamed lack of investment.\n\nIn an 8-hour work day, the study found employees and business leaders being genuinely productive for 5.8 and 5.9 hours respectively, leaving over a quarter of the day unproductive and not generating business value.\n\nHowever, Daniel Pell, vice president and country manager for UK & Ireland at Workday, warned that AI would only reach its full potential if companies can build trust and align its use to business outcomes.\n\n\"We encourage businesses to take a two-pronged approach when it comes to deploying AI: a concrete analysis of the efficiencies AI can drive, alongside a transparent strategy to tackle the material and cultural barriers to its adoption.\"\n\nWorkday found that unengaged employees were the biggest barrier to productivity, and advised organisations to prioritise team motivation in order to unlock the full potential of AI.\n\nLast week, HR software company Lattice announced it would become the first business to 'onboard' digital employees in the same way as human workers.", "source": {"uri": "personneltoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Personnel Today"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8232677762", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "01:45:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T01:45:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T01:45:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3333333432674408, "url": "https://www.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202407/19/WS6699c505a31095c51c50ee01.html", "title": "Kingdee speeds up AI push for rapid tech advancement", "body": "Kingdee International Software Group Co Ltd, a Chinese software industry pioneer, has stepped up efforts to embrace artificial intelligence, with the aim of revolutionizing its products and solutions as well as cultivating new quality productive forces for the country's software sector.\n\nAs industries evolve in an era marked by rapid technological advancements, leveraging new ideas, methods, tools, technologies and elements is imperative, said Xu Shaochun, chairman and CEO of Kingdee.\n\n\"In the past, growth was driven by labor, capital and energy. However, in the future, data will emerge as a critical element in digital transformation, gaining increasing importance among enterprises. Consequently, Kingdee is committed to nurturing new quality productive forces to support high-quality corporate development,\" Xu said.\n\nKingdee, which has been offering management software and services for companies for over three decades, is focusing on its \"subscription priority, AI priority\" strategy this year to help enterprises accelerate their digital transformation, he said.\n\nXu said that the key to developing a digital economy lies in driving enterprises' digital transformation. This involves utilizing new technologies and concepts to develop next-generation enterprise management digital platforms, thereby enhancing enterprise business capability. This encompasses data-driven business operations, customer service and engagement, partner empowerment, asset management and employee enablement.\n\nXu's remarks were echoed by Kitty Fok, managing director of International Data Corp China.\n\nFok said China's digital transformation was mainly focused on the consumer level in the past, such as mobile payments, e-commerce and video-streaming platforms.\n\nThis means there is huge potential for companies in the country to accomplish their digital upgrade as a whole.\n\nIDC has forecast that 51 percent of global IT budgets will go toward digital innovation and digital transformation by 2024, while that number in China is estimated to be above 70 percent.\n\nSpecifically, China's investment in AI is forecast to reach 273.9 billion yuan ($38.1 billion) in 2027, accounting for 9 percent of the world's total, IDC said.\n\nThe Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, China's top industry regulator, has also said that it would launch an \"AI plus\" initiative to promote the application of the technology in more sectors.\n\nThat would spell significant opportunities for companies like Kingdee.\n\n\"In the realm of financial management, AI has revolutionized the traditional framework, and the shift from experience-based forecasting to AI-precise forecasting represents a significant change,\" Xu said.\n\nAccording to him, while traditional methods rely on subjective experience and limited data, AI integrates big data correlation analysis and deep learning, enabling more accurate revenue, cost, profit and risk predictions. This adaptability to changing environments and needs exemplifies the profound impact of AI.\n\nMoreover, the scope of expert service management has expanded from relying on individual experts to utilizing AI \"teams\". In specialized areas such as taxation, treasury and capital operations, AI can now provide cross-industry, multiskilled solutions, akin to having numerous experts at one's disposal, Xu added.\n\nFor instance, Kingdee said its collaboration with a bank employs multi-feature recall and financial model technology to automatically screen transaction data daily, aiding enterprises in preventing fraudulent trade risks.\n\n\"The introduction of AI also transforms workforce dynamics. A finance department originally staffed with 500 employees can now achieve the output of 1,000 people, with AI significantly enhancing productivity. Conversely, AI can maintain the department's capabilities even if the workforce is reduced to 200, showcasing its value,\" Xu said.\n\nIn May 2024, Kingdee launched its intelligent AI management assistant, Cosmic, and upgraded its Kingdee Cloud Cosmic platform into a new-generation enterprise-level AI platform. Notable collaborations include Chinese property developer C&D Real Estate Corp Ltd, which has partnered with Kingdee to develop a contract management system powered by AI, marking a big boost in work efficiency.\n\nSimilarly, Hisense Group and Kingdee co-created AI applications in human resources management.\n\nAs of March 31, Kingdee International reported an annual recurring revenue of about 2.98 billion yuan from cloud subscription services, a 28 percent year-on-year increase.\n\nIn the first half, Kingdee secured contracts with large enterprises, including China National Petroleum Corp, China National Aviation Holding Corp, Dongfeng Motor Corp, and Longfor Group.\n\nThe progress is the result of Kingdee's long-term emphasis on research and development. In 2023, Kingdee's R&D expenditure was approximately 1.44 billion yuan, accounting for about 25.4 percent of the group's total revenue.\n\n\"The goal is to enhance the digital management value of Chinese enterprises. By empowering our entire product line with AI, Kingdee aims for disruptive innovation, ensuring that every user benefits from an AI assistant,\" Xu said.", "source": {"uri": "chinadaily.com.cn", It is the first comprehensive legal framework for the regulation of AI systems across the EU and will closely follow the prior versions of the text, which can be found here. The EU AI Act will enter into force across all EU Member States on August 1, 2024, and the enforcement of the majority of its provisions will apply from August 2, 2026. However, it is subject to a transition period and, therefore, will become applicable in stages. Some key dates are outlined below:\n\nNon-compliance with EU AI Act can result in the imposition of fines of up to \u20ac35 million or 7% of total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher.", "source": {"uri": "lexology.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Lexology"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Artificial intelligence"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "European Union"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence_Act", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Artificial Intelligence Act"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Member state of the European Union"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euro", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Euro"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral", "label": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 46}], "image": "https://www.lexology.com/images/share/lexology-social-media.png", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9737001", "eventUri": "eng-9737001", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-07-", "textStart": 3, "textEnd": 10}], "sentiment": 0.1686274509803922, "wgt": 84, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8228271840", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-16", "time": "13:04:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-16T13:04:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-16T13:03:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.1725490242242813, "url": "https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=9e22a28b-d8f9-424e-a5ba-8020916885c5", "title": "EU AI Act Will Formally Become Law and Provisions Will Start to Apply on a Staged Basis", "body": "As previously discussed, in March the European Parliament approved the EU Artificial Intelligence Act (the \"Act\"), creating the world's first comprehensive set of rules for artificial intelligence. On July 12, 2024, the Act was published in the European Union Official Journal, which is the final step in the EU legislative process.\n\nThe Act will enter into force on August 2, 2024, with the majority of the provisions applying from August 2, 2026. The ban on AI systems that pose an unacceptable risk will come into force on February 2, 2025, and the obligations for high-risk systems will apply from August 2, 2027.\n\nThis Regulation shall be binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States without the need for additional domestic legislation.", "source": {"uri": "lexology.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Lexology"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "European Union"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence_Act", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Artificial Intelligence Act"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Artificial intelligence"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Parliament", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "European Parliament"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Member state of the European Union"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral", "label": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://www.lexology.com/images/share/lexology-social-media.png", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9737001", "eventUri": "eng-9737001", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-07-", "textStart": 201, "textEnd": 208}], "sentiment": 0.0117647058823529, "wgt": 44, "relevance": 1}
